                     <h2 class="date-header">July 06, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003703"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3703">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Special Edition of The Ojai Bubble</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>   <img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Bubble%20cover%20Vol%202%282%29.JPG" width="612" height="792" alt="Bubble cover Vol 2(2).JPG"/></p>

<p>A Note from Nancy Gross of The Ojai Bubble.</p>

<p>     The Ojai Bubble July 2010 issue is at Ojai Printing and will be out and around in a few days. The issue is themed around French Connections to Ojai, in light of Bastille Day on July 14, and the French Festival in Santa Barbara on July 17 and 18. To view a small sampling of what is within, visit The Ojai Bubbleâs Facebook page. <br />
     With 28 pages of articles, photographs and poems, it is not only thicker than Volume 1; it is more consistent visually, while still playful and colorful. Perhaps Steve Grumette enhancing my photos, and having three professional photographers contribute are the reasons the pages look so pretty. And, as I received a suggestion here, a suggestion there, from Anca Colbert, my daughter Ivy Anderson, P. Lyn Middleton, Myrna Cambianica, and others, I grew in the graphics role. </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/07/special_edition_of_the_ojai_bu.shtml">Continue reading "Special Edition of The Ojai Bubble" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                        <div class="entry-content">

                              <p>Tonight at Chaparral Auditorium, 414 E Ojai Ave, 7pm, check out a presentation by Brock Dolman, Director of the WATER Institute and author of Basins of Relations: Think Like a Watershed.  This will be preceded by a short film: The Cycle of Insanity: The Real Story of Water.</p>

<blockquote> Matilija Junior High School students are competing in a talent show Friday, May 28 at 7:00PM in the schoolâs auditorium.  âMATILIJAâS GOT TALENTâ will feature 10 acts.                      <a id="a003689"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3689">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Zeretzke Award At Libbey Bowl 7pm Tonight!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The City of Ojai will present John Zeretzke with a Lifetime Achievement Award tonight to kick off the Nordhoff High School Jazz Band concert at 7pm.  The Arts Commission decided to move the ceremony to the bowl because of all the students he has influenced will be there at the same time as the city council meeting.  The council meeting will proceed as usual at 7:30.  And thank you Bill Wagner for honoring our request.  So, if you planned to go to the city council meeting, come over to the Libbey Bowl for the ceremony and honor John and the work he does in arts education and  support  the Nordhoff Jazz Band and  Should be great fun!</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Demitri Corbin at 09:11 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/05/zeretzke_award_at_libbey_bowl.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">May 23, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003686"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3686">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">OBC Salutes Food Share with Craft Beer and Fine Food</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.salutebeerfestival.com/index.html" target="_blank"><img  src="http://www.salutebeerfestival.com/files/SaluteLogo.gif" border="3" align="right" alt="Salute Beer Festival"></a> Here's a cool Father's Day Weekend event that's making me thirsty. <br />
If you love to celebrate with finely crafted beers, delicious food and hang out at the beach, then the <a href="http://ojaibevco.com">Ojai Beverage Company</a> and <a href="http://33productions.com">33 Productions, Inc</a>. have put together just the event for you. <br />
On June 19 <a href="http://salutebeerfestival.com">The Salute Beer Festival</a> will bring a variety of widely acclaimed breweries, restaurants and live musical entertainment to the Ventura State Beach. Net proceeds from the event are being donated to <a href="http://www.foodshare.com">Food Share</a>; Ventura County's regional food bank, which feeds more than 55,000 people through 150 plus partner agencies in Ventura County. That's a worthy cause to celebrate.<br />
With dozens of American Craft Breweries and the regions finest restaurants signed on for the for the beer and food pairing event, the blessing of the California Small Brewers Association, music by Jack Maness of Sublime and Long Beach Dub All Stars the only real thing left to let you know is to buy your tickets at <a href="http://salutebeerfestival.com">salutebeerfestival.com</a>. General Admission $50, VIP $125 until June 1, then $60 and $135 respectively.<br />
Props to Joby Yobe of OBC and Christine Hansen of 33 Productions for putting together such an impressive lineup. Full press release after the jump.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/05/obc_salutes_food_share_with_cr.shtml">Continue reading "OBC Salutes Food Share with Craft Beer and Fine Food" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>from the fine folk at Ojai Music Festival...</em></p>

<p>Frank Zappa, Americaâs great musical iconoclast and innovator, once said âa composer is a guy who goes around forcing his will on unsuspecting air molecules, often with the assistance of unsuspecting musicians.â Famous to some for his rock band âThe Mothers of Invention,â and to others for his sharp tongue and avant-garde classical music, Zappa enjoyed a legendary career that spanned more than 30 years and astonished the world by breaching the barriers of musical genres.</p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Volunteers needed for Ojai Music Festival</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>from the fine folk at the Ojai Music Festival...</em></p>

<p>The Ojai Music Festival is still recruiting volunteers to assist at the 64th Festival slated for June 10 to 13, 2010.  Volunteer positions include hospitality, production, set up, security, ushering, artist liaisons, and office assistance. This is an exciting and fun way to experience the Ojai Music Festival from behind the scenes and meet new people. </p>

                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3676">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">33rd Annual Art in the Park</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>PR from the Ojai Art Center...</em></p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Succulent%20oil%20painting%20by%20Iris.jpg" width="150" height="146" alt="Succulent oil painting by Iris.jpg" align="left" style="margin: 2px 6px 2px 0;"/>Memorial Day weekend takes on an added degree of excitement May 29th and 30th with the return of one of Ojaiâs main cultural events, the 33rd annual Art in the Park.  The open-air juried show draws artists and art lovers from all over southern California to Libbey Park for two days of sales and socializing. From 10:00 a.m. until 5:00 pm. Saturday and Sunday the park will come alive with the art and chatter of over 50 artists hoping to make a connection and sell their work. Art lovers will be there to purchase their newest treasure or just to have a chance to appreciate the newest work of a previously unknown artist.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/zeretzke1.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/zeretzke1.shtml', 'popup', 'width=450,height=385,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0' ); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/zeretzke1-thumb.jpg" width="120" height="102" alt="zeretzke1.jpg" align="left" style="margin: 2px 6px 2px 0;" /></a>  I first met Zeretzke on the back patio of Local Hero (now Feast Bistro), on a beautiful Ojai summer night. He and tenor Mark Llewellyn were performing lilting ballads that floated on the evening air. The audience knew they were in the presence of two uncommonly talented and unique musicians when Zeretzke began to make weird, unearthly sound effects to accompany the old whaling song they sang, the sounds of breaching whales. This he accomplished on an electronic violin and a handmade set of rare Bulgarian bagpipes.</p>

                     <a id="a003650"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3650">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Feel Good Music in Ojai</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/songwriter%20Joe%20Reilly.jpeg" alt="songwriter Joe Reilly.jpeg" height="100" width="71" align="right"></p>

<p>Have you ever been to a concert and just end up smiling the entire time because the music is positive, fun, and creative? A performance where the energy is just right, the lyrics are inspirational, and the performer is happy to be alive and share? <strong><a href="http://www.joereilly.org/">Joe Reilly</a></strong> is that performer and he'll be in Ojai on <strong>Tuesday</strong> performing in the <a href="http://www.soulcentered.com/">Soul Centered</a> dome at 7pm. Tickets at the door.</p>

<blockquote>Joe Reilly's heart is an infinite ocean and each song that he writes is a resonant wave. We call him Spiritboy because when he aligns his hands, his heart, and his harmonies, he not only displays his personal emotional journey, he also plucks the heartstrings of hope to bring us beyond despair into healing action. His heart has been nurtured by Native American, Buddhist, and Catholic teachings. As a result, he can howl a chilling splash-in-the face blues about treachery and historical injustice and inspire you with upbeat ditties that echo in your mind long afterwards.</blockquote>

<p>Joe is from Michigan and this will be his second pass through Ojai. In the years I've known Joe,  I've discovered that he is gentle, kind, loving, musical, creative, and fun. His music his perfect for kids of all ages and most who leave wanting more. </p>

<p><a href="http://www.myspace.com/joereillymusic/music/playlists">Listen to select tracks.</a></p>

                     <a id="a003630"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3630">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Arts and Entertainment Notes</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Get out and have some fun!</p>

<p><strong>This weekend:</strong> <a href="http://www.ojaivalleygreencoalition.org/2010/04/earthplay_on_the_meadow.shtml" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">EarthPlay on the Meadow</a>, <a href="http://www.ojaitourney.org/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">The 110th Ojai Valley Tennis Tournament</a> and the <a href="http://www.ojaiartcenter.org/specialevents.htm" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Madrigali at the Art Center</a></p>

                     <a id="a003627"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3627">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Libbey Bowl Exhibit at the Museum</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>good stuff from the fine folk at the Ojai Valley Museum...</em></p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/1972%20Krishnamurtie%20at%20the%20Bowl_web-1.jpg" width="299" height="183" alt="1972 Krishnamurtie at the Bowl_web-1.jpg"/></p>

<p>In Ojai, California, an outdoor landmark of world-renown will be razed to the ground on June 21, 2010 and reconstruction will begin immediately thereafter. Beginning in 1957, Ojaiâs Libbey Bowl amphitheater has gathered international music and theatre groups attracting audiences from southern to northern California, and from east coast to west coast. As a tribute to the past, present and future of Ojaiâs Libbey Bowl, the Ojai Valley Museum will mount an historical exhibition showcasing the highlights of the Bowlâs first 50 years, and the plans for its reconstruction and future use. </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/04/libbey_bowl_exhibit_at_the_mus.shtml">Continue reading "Libbey Bowl Exhibit at the Museum" &raquo;</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">April 16, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003616"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3616">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Deep Time and The Meaning of Life -- Sunday, April 18th, at the Ojai Retreat</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Sunday, April 18,  2:00pm-4:00pm<br />
<a href="http://ojairetreat.com/">Ojai Retreat </a> 160 Besant Road in Ojai (above the Ranch House Restaurant)</p>

<p>The story of the development of life on Earth is not just a theory for biology books. It is the key to understanding our world today â not only our environment, but the moral and spiritual dimensions of our world as well.</p>

<p>This is the theme of âDeep Time and the Meaning of Lifeâ, a talk to be given by David E. Moody, Ph.D. Dr. Moodyâs talk explores the intersection between science and the sacred. It examines the extraordinary mystery of why our planet is so perfectly suited for life, with just the right climate and chemistry for us and all living things. Did this happen because God made it this way? Or are we just lucky? Or is there a deeper, more interesting explanation?</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/04/deep_time_and_the_meaning_of_l.shtml">Continue reading "Deep Time and The Meaning of Life -- Sunday, April 18th, at the Ojai Retreat" &raquo;</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">April 10, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003599"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3599">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Save Libbey Bowl...why?</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The first year that Sweetie and I moved to Ojai we attended the Music Festival.  We had no idea what to expect, including the Libbey Bowl wooden benches imported from Spain after Torquemada had finished with them.</p>

<p>We sat close to the front, not wanting to miss a dulcet tone, a memorable phrase, a catchy tune.  Warmly placed between what turned out to be veteran Festival goers, we patiently waited for the program to begin.  A middle-aged man emerged to polite applause, plunked himself before the impressive Steinway and began to play.  Itâs been years since we experienced his performance and perhaps my memory is a bit clouded, but I swear he was playing with his elbows.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Bowl-Pano-2-Blog.jpg" width="400" height="131" alt="Bowl-Pano-2-Blog.jpg"/></p>

                     <a id="a003576"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3576">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Center for the Arts---2010 Photo Show</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Call for Artists!</p>

<p><strong>Eat!</strong></p>

<p>A Photography Exhibit at the Ojai Center for the Arts</p>

<p>EAT is the theme of this yearâs photograph exhibition at the Ojai Center for the Arts. The seventh annual juried show celebrating food and eating encourages any photographic style including photojournalism, agrarian landscapes, food stills, photomontages, etc. The show opens June 5 and runs through July 7, 2010. </p>

<p>Last year more than 40 works by nearly as many photographers were displayed at the Art Center.  This year we expect that more artists will compete to have one or more of their works in the show.</p>

<p>Photographers are invited to submit their work on June 3 or June 4.  Detailed submission information can be found on the <a href="http://www.bearwoodimages.com/photobranch">Photography Branch page </a>of the Art Center website.</p>

<p>Gallery hours are Tuesday through Sunday from 12 to 4 pm. Admission is free. There will be a reception Sunday, June 6 from 1 to 3:30 pm. Refreshments will be served. The Art Center is located in downtown Ojai at 113 South Montgomery Street.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 26, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003572"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3572">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Reminder to see, "The Power of Community: How Cuba Survived Peak Oil," Saturday, March 27th</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>Film Showing -- Power of Community: How Cuba Survived Peak Oil</strong><br />
<em>Opening remarks by </em><a href="http://vote.daswilliams.org">Das Williams </a></p>

<p>Click here for film poster: <strong><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/POC_Poster.pdf">POC_Poster.pdf</a></strong></p>

<p>On Saturday afternoon, March 27th, at 4:30pm at the Ojai Theatre, the Ojai Valley Green Coalition will make a special presentation of the documentary film, <em>The Power of Community: How Cuba Survived Peak Oil</em>.</p>

<p>The film focuses on the oil supply crisis that the collapse of the Soviet Union brought upon Cuba. This Cuban experience of the 1990s offers lessons to help prepare other nations with petroleum-based economiesâsuch as our ownâfor a future in which oil will become more more expensive and could eventually be unavailable.</p>

<p>Speaking prior to the film screening will be Santa Barbara City Councilmember <a href="http://vote.daswilliams.org/">Das Williams</a>, who grew up in Ojai. He is a candidate for the California State Assembly and a community organizer for the Ventura-based nonprofit CAUSE, <br />
<a href="http://www.coastalalliance.com/">Coastal Alliance United for a Sustainable Economy</a><br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/03/reminder_to_see_the_power_of_c.shtml">Continue reading "Reminder to see, "The Power of Community: How Cuba Survived Peak Oil," Saturday, March 27th" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 04:14 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/03/reminder_to_see_the_power_of_c.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/03/reminder_to_see_the_power_of_c.shtml#comments">Comments (3)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../suza.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 24, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003565"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3565">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojaiâs 33rd Art in the Park</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>A little something from the Ojai Art Center aimed at our fine city's visitors...</em></p>

<p>The time is now to think art. If you are a fine artist or appreciate the arts make your plans now to visit Ojai, one of Californiaâs best art towns.                         <h3 class="entry-header">" Always remember to preheat your pan before using."</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">

                     <a id="a003559"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3559">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ah, the theatre, the theatre!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><br />
There are two theatre events this weekend that I'd like to recommend.  Two gay-themed plays being performed this weekend and I urge you to see them both.  The first to tell you of is<a href="http://www.108productions.org"> Corpus Christi </a>by Terrence McNally.  In the 1990's there were three notable plays by gay authors.  I had the good fortune of being in two of them. <a href="http://www.answers.com/paul-rudnick-writer-actor-comedy">Jeffrey</a> by Paul Rudnick and <a href="http://youtube.com/watch?v=jTDcbJcCGTE">Angels in America</a> by Tony Kushner.  Jeffrey, an Off-Broadway sex romp and Angels, an 8-hour gay fantasia on national themes, both had long runs and critical acclaim.  Terrence McNally didn't fair as well. He got <a href="http://thefileroom.org/html/368.html">death threats</a> for the 1998 production of Corpus Christi.  More notable for the furor from the religious right than for it's artistic success, it opened to less than glowing reviews.  It has been revived over the years in various productions with better success than the original and comes to Ojai this weekend courtesy of Ojai's own John Grant and 108 Productions.  The troupe is on the last legs of a tour that began in 2008 and will end this Spring in San Francisco.  They're traveling with a documentary film crew, so it will be nice to have Ojai included in the mix.  </p>

<p>Speaking of Jeffrey, that is my connection to the actor in Theater 150's Solo Series presentation of <a href="http://www.broadwayworld.com/printcolumn.cfm?id=20605">Bent to the Flame.</a>  I met the playwright and actor Doug Tompos on Jeffrey.  He was assigned to teach me the roles I would be taking over.  Years later we worked catering in Los Angeles and I've not seen him for sometime until last Saturday's matinÃ©e.  Bent to the Flame tells us the story of a young Tennessee Williams, fresh on the heels of his success with A Glass Menagerie, as he is prepares to address an audience gathered to hear a lecture on the work of a controversial gay poet.  Doug gave a wonderful performance.  The only complaint I have about the production is that there were only 4 people in the audience!!  Let's hope that Ojai will come out and support the visiting artists this coming weekend.  </p>

<p>Corpus Christi is being presented at the Zalk Theatre of the Besant Hill School in Upper Ojai on March 26, 27, and 28.   Show times are 7:30pm.  Tickets are $25.00 @108productions.org or call 640-1210 or visit the Ojai Theatre Box Office at 146 E. Ojai Ave.</p>

<p>Bent to the Flame is playing in repertory with The Common Air, Friday March 26 and Saturday, March 27 at 7:30pm and Sunday March 28 at 2pm.  Tickets are $25.00 Friday and Saturday, $15.00 on Sunday<br />
Theater 150 is located at 316 E. Matilija Street.  Visit theater150.org or call (805)-640-4300</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Demitri Corbin at 12:16 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/03/ah_the_theatre_the_theatre.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/03/ah_the_theatre_the_theatre.shtml#comments">Comments (1)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../demitri.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 16, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003503"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3503">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Freedom: A Haiku</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Today is Day 18 of the 64-Day Season for Nonviolence that spans the death dates of Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King, Jr.  <a href="http://bit.ly/a8BCPD">One source</a> lists the following as today's Quotation, Affirmation, and Practice, and i thought the OP community might enjoy participating!:</p>

<blockquote><h3>FREEDOM: 
<br><br><u>Quotation:</u> <em>"Every human has four endowments - self awareness, conscience, independent will, and creative imagination. These give us the ultimate human freedom... The power to choose, to respond, to change."</em> -Stephen Covey
<br><br><u>Affirmation:</u>
Freedom means that we have the independent will to act and respond creatively, that we have the self-awareness to self-reflect and to change as dictated by the compass of conscience. Moment by moment today, I become conscious of my freedom.
<br><br><u>Practice:</u> Claim your definition of freedom.  Write a haiku poem about freedom.</h3></blockquote>
<br><br><em>These affirmations are updated EVERY DAY at <a href="http://bit.ly/b5p5TQ">ojaipeace.org</a>.</em>

                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/02/freedom_a_haiku_1.shtml#comments">Comments (1)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../evan.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 11, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003499"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3499">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Bear Art Dedication â Friday, Feb. 12, 4 pm, Fountain Plaza</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>An Invitation from Marcia Benkert</strong></p>

<p>Although the notice is short, Iâm excited to share the news, and invite you to an important Public Art Dedication, in Ojai, California, Friday, February 12, 2010, at 4:00 p.m., 328 E. Ojai Avenue (fountain plaza behind Bonnie Luâs).</p>

<p>This majestic, steel sculpture of a Black Bear represents a memorial to our respected wildlife, and a reminder to ourselves, of the painful lessons that we, as a community, have needed to learn in order to effect a change in the way we respond to innocent animals wandering into our neighborhoods.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/02/bear_art_dedication_friday_feb.shtml">Continue reading "Bear Art Dedication â Friday, Feb. 12, 4 pm, Fountain Plaza" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 10, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003497"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3497">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Music Habits</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>It's never a bad time to talk about music. Here's a group of songs (song, artist, release) that I've put together as a playlist for myself.</p>

<ul>
<li>The Road, Nick Cave &amp; Warren Ellis, The Road Original Film Score</li>
<li>Flume, Peter Gabriel, Scratch My Back</li>
<li>Summer Fog, The Album Leaf, A Chorus of Storytellers</li>
<li>Broken Horse, Freelance Whales, Weathervanes</li>
<li>All the Way, David Ahlen, All the Way the Savior Leads Me</li>
<li>The Department of Dead Letters, David Sylvian, Manafon</li>
<li>VCR, The xx, xx</li>
<li>Plastic People, Four Tet, There is Love in You</li>
<li>Joy Maker Machinery, Sweet Billy Pilgrim, Twice Born Men</li>
<li>Wooden Arms, Patrik Watson, Wooden Arms</li>
<li>Harm, Loney Dear, Dear John</li>
<li>Bellwether, Joe Henry, Blood From Stars</li>
<li>Canvas, Imogen Heap, Ellipse</li>
<li>Mean to Me, Nellie McKay, Normal As Blueberry Pie</li>
</ul>

<p>You could probably find most of this on <a href="http://myspace.com">myspace</a>, <a href="http://last.fm">last.fm</a>, or <a href="http://mog.com">MOG</a> but I may also put together a recording to share. Look in the comments in the future.  For the record, Joe Henry, Four Tet, The Album Leaf, and Peter Gabriel are all playing in Los Angeles in the near future. </p>

<p>What are you listening to?</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 08, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003492"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3492">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Great Stuff from the Green Coalition</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>Ojai Creek Riparian Habitat Restoration Project Phase 2</strong><br />
Saturday, February 20 and 27 - 9:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. Rain or shine, Libbey Park Gazebo<br />
Join the Watershed Committee in a native planting and non-native plant removal project, to reestablish a functioning wetland and riparian ecosystem that supports a diversity of fish and wildlife species and to improve the flow of water.  How: wear sturdy shoes, long-sleeved shirts, and pants, and bring gloves. Tools will be provided, but if you can bring your own shovel and/or trowel, that would help.  Call 805-669-8445 for more info.</p>

<p><strong>Our Seeds: come to the film, stay for the seed swap</strong><br />
Saturday, February 27, 4:30pm, Ojai Theatre<br />
Join the Green Coalition at the theatre for a movie on Seeds, generously sponsored by Nutiva.   All are welcome, $10 suggested donation.  For more info call 805-669-8445.<br />
</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">January 12, 2010</h2>
                     <a id="a003442"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3442">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai City Council Appointment On Agenda Tonight, Tuesday, January 12, 2010</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>It should be an interesting meeting tonight!  This evening our City Council members will be deliberating on applicants for the vacancy created by the resignation of Joe DeVito last month. While appointing a fifth member to the council is a serious matter, I anticipate some humorous small town drama.</p>

<p>For those new to city meetings, they are held at Ojai City Hall, 401 S. Ventura Street. Meetings start at 7:30 p.m. This Item, "Appointment to City Council to Fill Unexpired Term," is number four on the agenda, so it <em>might</em> be after 8 p.m. before it comes up. I recommend arriving on time, if you can, so that you get your bearings, especially if you plan to speak at the podium for the candidate of your choice. </p>

<p>Delicious Pepperidge Farm cookies, coffee, assorted herbal teas and spring water are available in the city hall kitchen to add to the small-town friendliness of the meeting and to help keep you awake when things get bogged down. I have also been known to take home a handful of chocolate lady fingers to ease the pain of disappointment at the outcome -- or to celebrate small victories -- as the case may be.<br />
<strong>WARNING:</strong> <em>The coffee at city hall is real. This is not your low-caffeine-organic type brand. I drank it once and immediately felt a terrific jolt to my nervous system -- got the shakes and was up all night. </em></p>

<p><strong>Back to the matter at hand:</strong></p>

<p>As of this morning, five brave souls have applied for the position. In alphabetical order, the five candidates are: <br />
Paul Blatz, Demitri Corbin, Leonard Klaif, Mike Lenehan and John Mirk. </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/01/ojai_city_council_appointment_1.shtml">Continue reading "Ojai City Council Appointment On Agenda Tonight, Tuesday, January 12, 2010" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 06:42 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/01/ojai_city_council_appointment_1.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <a id="a003439"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3439">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Welcome to Transition Ojai! Learn All About Transition Towns Here.</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong><a href="http://transitionojai.org/index.html">Transition Ojai </a>is now live! </strong></p>

<p>The Transition Town movement represents one of the most promising ways of engaging people and communities to take the far-reaching actions that are required to mitigate the effects of peak oil, climate change and the economic crisis. Here in Ojai I see the Transition Town model as a way to bring together and empower many different community projects, organizations and endeavors that are part of creating a sustainable community.</p>

<p>The first in a series of informative Transition Town meetings will be held on Tuesday, January 12, 7pm, at 1215 Drown Avenue, Ojai (above Grand, last house on left before intersection with Pleasant Ave).<br />
For more information contact Wayne Thompson at  805 798 2152 or e-mail <a href="mailto:transitionojai@gmail.com">transitionojai@gmail.com</a></p>

<p><strong>How Do Transition Towns Begin? </strong></p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/01/welcome_to_transition_ojai_lea.shtml">Continue reading "Welcome to Transition Ojai! Learn All About Transition Towns Here." &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Inspiration for 2010: "I Am Potential"</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The caption that came with the video below said, "Love is the answer to overcome anything." After watching it, I would add, "Having good parents helps alot!"</p>

<p>This video is a peek into the life of Patrick Henry Hughes, who was born with an extremely rare genetic disorder: arms that could not straighten, legs that would never be able to walk, and most devastating of all, permanent blindness. He had been born with no eyes -- the eyes he has are artificial. It shows him as a baby, and later as a toddler, playing the piano.  <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9xwCG0Ey2Mg">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9xwCG0Ey2Mg</a><br />
 <br />
<strong>About Patrick Henry Hughes, author of <em>I Am Potential</em>.</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.patrickhenryhughes.com ">www.patrickhenryhughes.com </a></p>

                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 06:19 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2010/01/inspiration_for_2010_i_am_pote.shtml">Permalink</a>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Early Morning in Ojai at the Dawn of the New Year </h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">

                              <p>I head out in the dark<br />
to catch the magic moment --<br />
the crack of dawn</p>

is contagious</p>

and the full moon<br />
is hanging high in the sky<br />
by an etheric thread</p>

                     <a id="a003423"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3423">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Krotona in the Ojai Valley</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>From the fine folk at the OV Museum...</em></p>

<p>Join historian and author Joseph Ross for a presentation and booksigning at the Ojai Valley Museum, Sunday, Jan. 10 from 1 to 3 pm. Rossâs latest book, <em>Krotona in the Ojai Valley</em>, is a portrait of the prominent theosophists that colored the economic, cultural and spiritual life of the unique Ojai community in the 1920's. </p>

<p><br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/12/krotona_in_the_ojai_valley.shtml">Continue reading "Krotona in the Ojai Valley" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Museum Docent Program </h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>from the fine folk at the OV Museum...</em></p>

<p>What was the original name of the Ojai Playhouse in 1914 when it first opened?   How were prisoners in the Ojai jail kept in line without a guard ever being posted?  Where can you find the largest collection of fountains in the valley?   If questions like this intrigue you and you enjoy history, you may be interested in working with the Ojai Valley Museum docents, a group of volunteers that are the glue holding the daily museum operations together.  </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">December 12, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003392"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3392">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Oui Wii</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>I am a latecomer to the world of Wii, my appetite for video games dying with Atari's passing many years ago. For some reason, if the game's champions and villains aren't primitive low-res insects, monsters, or spaceships, they have no appeal to me.</p>
<p>
So I was more than a little surprised when a box of Wii showed up at our door several weeks ago. Apparently, a neighbor had hooked my wife on Wii Fit. I set it up and she started Wii-ing like a teenager. It wasn't long before she convinced me to give it a try.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/12/oui_wii.shtml">Continue reading "Oui Wii" &raquo;</a>

                     <a id="a003374"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3374">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai-Ventura International Film Festival: David Shor Releases Statement About Resignations</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>On Saturday evening, the following email was issued: </em></p>

<p>-----Original Message-----<br />
From: OJAI-VENTURA INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL <ojaiventurafilmfestival@gmail.com><br />
To: OJAI-VENTURA FILM FESTIVAL INTERNATIONAL <ojaiventurafilmfestival@gmail.com><br />
Sent: Sat, Dec 5, 2009 8:07 pm<br />
Subject: FILM FESTIVAL RERSIGNATIONS</p>

<p>Please be advised that the following officers and directors of the Ojai Film Festival Corporation d/b/a Ojai-Ventura International Film Festival have resigned:</p>

<p>David Shor<br />
Rinaldo Brutoco<br />
James Holland<br />
Sheila Cluff<br />
Bill Monot<br />
Lori Wyatt<br />
John Bennet Perry</p>

<p><em>Moments ago, David Shor, former Board Chairman and President of the festival, released the following statement:</em></p>

<p>I am proud of where I was able to take the festival as its board chairman and president, essentially leading it from its demise a few years ago to the position of acclaim it achieved this year. Over the course of the last three years a new strategic plan was developed and executed to expand the festival and attract wider audiences and serve a broader geographic area within Ventura County. As a result the festival expanded into Ventura, formed strategic partnerships with the Ojai Valley Inn & Spa and Brooks Institute, began the Celebrity Golf Classic, changed its name to the Ojai-Ventura International Film Festival, and for the first time attracted very capable and committed directors & officers from outside of Ojai. Additionally, many new donors, sponsors & advertisers signed-on with the festival and enabled the expansion into new venues, expanded special events and screenings, and the festival attracted the best films in its history. A relationship with the British Academy of Film & Television Arts (BAFTA) was formed along with many other special and meaningful relationships. <em>(continued after the jump)</em></p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/12/ojaiventura_international_film_3.shtml">Continue reading "Ojai-Ventura International Film Festival: David Shor Releases Statement About Resignations" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">'Fallen Angels' join The Men of Ojai This Thursday</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/fallen-angel1.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/fallen-angel1.shtml', 'popup', 'width=503,height=760,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0' ); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/fallen-angel-thumb.jpg" width="150" height="226" alt="fallen-angel.jpg" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="10" /></a>âFallen Angels,â by photographer Bobbi Bennett will featured in a gallery show with The Men of Ojai 2010 Calendar collection this Thursday, December 3, 6 to 9pm at Casa Barranca Wine Tasting Room, 208 East Ojai Ave. Bennett has exhibited nationally and is widely collected.  Her work joins that of Attasalina Dews in the 2010 Men of Ojai Calendar. The image "Fallen Angels" is in the permanent collection at the Santa Barbara Museum of Art at "50 x72".  </p>

<p>Two original (20X24) c-prints and digital prints will be available for purchase at the Thursday evening fund raising event. The Men of Ojai portraits will also be auctioned. </p>

<p>Admission is $30 and  includes one  Men of Ojai 2010 Calendar, 2 glasses of Casa Barranca wine and edibles from Azu, Feast Bistro and Osteria Monte Grappa. Ticket stubs are redeemable for10%  discounts at the three eateries and 20% discounts at Casa Barranca Wine Tasting Room through the holiday season.  Proceeds  benefit Ojai Calendar Project, an nonprofit organization dedicated to funding the arts in the Ojai Valley. For tickets and information visit www.menofojai.com or call 805-603-0079. </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">November 22, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003343"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3343">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Save Thanksgiving!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <div style="align: left;"><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/IMGP2984.JPG"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/IMGP2984-thumb.JPG" width="180" height="144" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="IMGP2984.JPG"/></a></div>Thanksgiving needs our help!  Specifically, the "<a href="http://onecityventura.org/">One City</a>" Thanksgiving meal and celebration now in its second year in nearby Ventura. This all-volunteer event is hosted by a collective of faith, business, non-proï¬t 
and government organizations all working together for a better Ventura, and is "to include representatives from all of Ventura, friendly faces both young and old, rich and poor, tall and short, east and west, here and there" said VSSTF member Jack Broms, M.D.  <strong>A restaurant that was to cook most of the turkey backed out for reasons unknown, and the event is now scrambling to enlist Volunteer Chefs to prepare a few key dishes!  Distributed instructions are as follows:</strong>

<blockquote>1. Select a tray(s) to prepare: mashed potatoes, dressing, green beans, or turkey.

<p>2. Purchase food item(s) and large foil baking tray or pick up a tray at no cost from <a href="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=500+high+point+drive,+ventura,+ca&sll=34.291391,-119.197053&sspn=0.0245,0.037251&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=500+High+Point+Dr,+Ventura,+California+93003&z=16&iwloc=r0">Ventura Missionary Church</a>.  Turkeys will also be available at no cost beginning 11/19 at Ventura Missionary.  One tray should yield approximately 40 servings.</p>

<p>3. Prepare the dish* at home and place in full size foil baking tray.</p>

<p>4. Cover.  Label.  Refrigerate.</p>

<p>5. Deliver to rear entrance of the <a href="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=knights+of+columbus,+ventura&sll=34.290405,-119.197949&sspn=0.01225,0.018625&g=500+high+point+drive,+ventura,+ca&ie=UTF8&hq=knights+of+columbus,&hnear=Ventura,+CA&ll=34.280606,-119.297361&spn=0.011808,0.018625&z=16&iwloc=A">Knights of Columbus Hall at 36 Figueroa</a>, downtown Ventura at 8:45am Thanksgiving morning.</p>

<p><em>*Turkeys are to be pulled and deboned right away, and immediately refrigerated.</em></blockquote></p>

<p>More information and full event press release follows:</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/11/save_thanksgiving.shtml">Continue reading "Save Thanksgiving!" &raquo;</a>

                     <a id="a003290"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3290">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">From Science Daily:  Presidential Election Outcome Changed Voters' Testosterone</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/10/091020181257.htm</p>

<p>ScienceDaily (Oct. 21, 2009) â Young men who voted for Republican John McCain or Libertarian candidate Robert Barr in the 2008 presidential election suffered an immediate drop in testosterone when the election results were announced, according to a study by researchers at Duke University and the University of Michigan.</p>

<p>In contrast, men who voted for the winner, Democrat Barack Obama, had stable testosterone levels immediately after the outcome.</p>

<p>Female study participants showed no significant change in their testosterone levels before and after the returns came in.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/10/from_science_daily_presidentia.shtml">Continue reading "From Science Daily:  Presidential Election Outcome Changed Voters' Testosterone" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">October 15, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003260"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3260">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">The Story of the Bear Sculpture</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Each morning this week, when I step outside my door to go to to work, I see the silhouette of a bear in the pine tree across the street. From this distance, it looks just like the several-hundred-pound black bear that I first discovered in the same position, on the same branch, last Saturday morning. But it is not him. It is a 70-pound metal sculpture created by my neighbor, <a href="http://www.markbenkertsculpture.com/">Mark Benkert</a>, honoring the memory of the bear. The following video tells the story of how it got there.</p>

<p><object width="480" height="295"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/YUUxub1dD_Y&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/YUUxub1dD_Y&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="480" height="295"></embed></object></p>

Stefano and Tammi have made some changes to the layout of the restaurant space to allow for a few more seats and created a fantastic rustic northern Italian menu (Stefano is from the region between Venice and Verona). Bill and I dined at Osteria Monte Grappa last night and were thrilled (ecstatic actually) to have another quality dining option in the Ojai Valley. Itâs also refreshing to see experienced restaurateurs at the helm. And, they brought one of their top chefs (Cesar) from Pane E Vino.</p>

<p>The menu is reasonably priced with countless offerings, including plenty of vegetarian options. The bambinos also have their own menu. We found the space to be a bit cramped and hot and the sloped floor an odd curiosity (our beverages were definitely tilting precariously in our neighborâs direction).</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">October 09, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003231"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3231">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">The Last Semester, Ojai's Nordhoff, 1909 - 2009</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>Memories by Susan Diets, Class of 1967</em></p>

<p>Last weekend I overcame my adolescent shyness and reunited with my old classmates and teachers at the Nordhoff Centennial Celebration.</p>

<p>Those of you who were around when the high school was first established in 1909 will recall that our whole town was once called Nordhoff, and that is how the high school got its name.  But in 1916, a group called the anti-Nordhoffians, with the help of the manager of the Foothills Hotel, Mr. Morse, convinced a hopelessly divided town to convert from "Nordhoff" to the new name, "Ojai."</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/10/the_last_semester_ojais_nordho.shtml">Continue reading "The Last Semester, Ojai's Nordhoff, 1909 - 2009" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 06:23 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/10/the_last_semester_ojais_nordho.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/10/the_last_semester_ojais_nordho.shtml#comments">Comments (5)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../suza.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>

<p>CPR, in conjunction with VC's International Studies Program, coordinates Ventura County's annual Earth Charter Summit and presents Earth Charter Awards to those community activists who best embody the Earth Charter's core values. Please join us in celebrating the Earth Charter and honoring the 8 local heroes and sheroes selected as this year's Ventura County ambassadors of Earth Charter Principles:</p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Forum on the New Economy: Updated Schedule of Events</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/OjaiForumFinal%20topSmall.jpg" width="450" height="100" alt="OjaiForumFinal topSmall.jpg"/></p>

<p>The vision for the forum is to create an annual international gathering on the New Economy in Ojai. Imagining into the new economy is focused on creating a sustainable future for ourselves and generations to come. We are not trying to fix the old but rather exploring new models and approaches, such as complementary currencies, mutual credit system, new investment tools, governance, and communications that builds healthy communities.</p>

<p>You are invited to participate in a deep exploration into the design of an action-based road map leading to new models for a vibrant economy in Ojai and beyond. The confluence of various tipping points in global, national and local economies have come together to provide an extraordinary opening for innovation and positive social change.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">September 12, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003159"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3159">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Forum on the New Economy - Register Now!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>http://www.ojaiforum.com/</strong><br />
<img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/OjaiForumFinal%20top.jpg" width="405" height="198" alt="OjaiForumFinal top.jpg"/></p>

<p>You are invited to participate in a deep exploration into the design of an action-based road map leading to new models for a vibrant economy in Ojai and beyond. The confluence of various tipping points in global, national and local economies have come together to provide an extraordinary opening for innovation and positive social change.</p>

<p>The vision for the forum is to create an annual international gathering on the New Economy in Ojai. Imagining into the new economy is focused on creating a sustainable future for ourselves and generations to come. We are not trying to fix the old but rather exploring new models and approaches, such as complementary currencies, mutual credit system, new investment tools, governance, and communications that builds healthy communities.</p>

<p><strong>http://www.ojaiforum.com/</strong></p>

<p><strong>Presenters: </p>

Howard Smith - Morgan Stanley Smith Barney<br />

                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3148">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Stop the "Gravel" Trucks: Live Video of Gravel Trucks Racing Down Maricopa Highway</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Rock%20the%20trucks%21%21FinalArt%20%20Trim%20Top%20small.jpg" width="450" height="220" alt="Rock the trucks!!FinalArt  Trim Top small.jpg"/></p>

<p>Check this out thrill ride.... Filmed from a motorcycle going up Maricopa Highway, Route 33, from just before the Double Tunnels to just past the Rose Valley turn off, you will dodge Gravel Trucks coming out from behind blind curves...<br />
 <br />
During these ten minutes you will pass no less than 5 double hoppers, most of which are clearly and dangerously crossing over the double yellow lines.  That's one truck every 2 minutes!<br />
 <br />
The first three appear at about 1:50 (one minute, 50 seconds in).  The fourth appears around  blind curve at around 8:25.  The fifth also crosses over the double yellow line at around 9:50.</p>

<p>You can advance the player if you want or just watch the whole thing from the bottom of the mountain to the top.  We suggest you turn your volume way down low!<br />
 <br />
Also, you can blow up to a Full Screen view (pretty wild!) by hitting the Google View tab at the bottom right of the Flash Player.</p>

                     <a id="a003147"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3147">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Forum on the New Economy, </h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/OjaiForumFinal%20top.jpg" width="450" height="220" alt="OjaiForumFinal top.jpg"/></p>

<p>You are invited to participate in a deep exploration into the design of an action-based road map leading to new models for a vibrant economy in Ojai and beyond. The confluence of various tipping points in global, national and local economies have come together to provide an extraordinary opening for innovation and positive social change.</p>

<p>The vision for the forum is to create an annual international gathering on the New Economy in Ojai. Imagining into the new economy is focused on creating a sustainable future for ourselves and generations to come. We are not trying to fix the old but rather exploring new models and approaches, such as complementary currencies, mutual credit system, new investment tools, governance, and communications that builds healthy communities.</p>

<p>Presenters: Lena Robinson (San Francisco Federal Reserve), David Brubaker (Ojai Community Bank), Tim Gallagher (Gallagher 20/20, Ventura County Star), Stephen Nellis (Pacific Coast Business Times), Rinaldo Brutoco (World Business Academy), Bruce Stenslie (Economic Development Collaborative), Dave Smith (Ventura County United Way),  Stuart Valentine (Iowa Progressive Asset Management), Hazel Henderson via live satellite remote, many more.</p>

<p><strong>http://www.ojaiforum.com/</strong></p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/09/ojai_forum_on_the_new_economy.shtml">Continue reading "Ojai Forum on the New Economy, " &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Howard Smith at 03:37 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/09/ojai_forum_on_the_new_economy.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">September 03, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003132"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3132">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">"War Child" at Ojai Playhouse</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><b>The <a href="http://www.livingpeaceinojai.com">Living Peace in Ojai</a> Peace Film Series presents "<a hre="http://warchildmovie.com/#">War Child</a>" at 4:30 pm on Saturday September 5th at the Ojai Playhouse/Theatre, admission is by donation.</b><br />
<a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/warchild.jpg"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/warchild-thumb.jpg" width="180" height="197" align="left" alt="warchild.jpg"/></a><br />
"Left home at the age of seven/one year later I'm carryin' an Ak-47." For hip hop artist Emmanuel Jal, a former child soldier in Sudan's brutal civil war, these lyrics are hardly empty posturing. They are the bitter reality of a young man who was "forced to sin" but determined to "never give up and never give in." Today, wounded but still hopeful, he fights a new battle: bringing peace to his beloved Sudan and building schools in Africa. This time, his weapon is a microphone. See why audiences from New York to Berlin to London rave about the award-winning film, War Child, and have embraced the hip-hop artist with a terrifying past and a gentle soul. Interspersing original interviews, live concerts, and rare footage of Jal as a seven year-old boy, War Child will make viewers cry, laugh, dance, and celebrate the power of hope.</p>

                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 09:46 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/09/war_child_at_ojai_playhouse.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <a id="a003130"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3130">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Stop the "Gravel" Trucks: Diesel Exhaust Linked To Cancer</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><u><strong>AN ARTICLE  THAT JUST APPEARED IN <em>SCIENCE DAILY</em> CONFIRMS SOME OF OUR GREATEST FEARS.</strong></u></p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Exhaust.jpg" width="300" height="333" alt="Exhaust.jpg"/></p>

<p>Damage to our air quality is one of the reasons the Coalition has been opposed to gravel trucks traveling through the Ojai Valley on their way from the Cuyama valley to Oxnard and Ventura.  Ojai has what is known as a "closed" air shed, which means that pollutants collect here in the valley and remain trapped.  Despite appearances that might suggest otherwise, Ojai has some of the worst air quality in the County.</p>

<p><strong>Scientists have demonstrated that the link between diesel fume exposure and cancer lies in the ability of diesel exhaust to induce the growth of new blood vessels that serve as a food supply for solid tumors.</strong></p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/09/stop_the_gravel_trucks_diesel.shtml">Continue reading "Stop the "Gravel" Trucks: Diesel Exhaust Linked To Cancer" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Howard Smith at 06:37 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/09/stop_the_gravel_trucks_diesel.shtml">Permalink</a>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">PR: In Concert - Paddy Keenan and Fionn O Lochlainn</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>i receive press releases... sounds like a fun event.</em></p>

<p>In the mid-1970s The Bothy Band forever changed the face of Irish traditional music. One of the bandâs founding members, and one of its driving forces, was uilleann piper Paddy Keenan. The virtuosity and ferocity of his playing led to his being described as âthe Jimi Hendrix of the pipesâ, and his style has continued to mature in the intervening years as he has pursued a solo career. Generally acknowledged as the most accomplished uilleann piper performing today, he is certainly one of the most brilliant musicians of his generation.</p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">The Government Can</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><object width="425" height="344"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/LO2eh6f5Go0&color1=0xb1b1b1&color2=0xcfcfcf&hl=en&feature=player_embedded&fs=1"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/LO2eh6f5Go0&color1=0xb1b1b1&color2=0xcfcfcf&hl=en&feature=player_embedded&fs=1" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowfullscreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" width="425" height="344"></embed></object></p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Mike Didj at 09:02 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/09/the_government_can.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/09/the_government_can.shtml#comments">Comments (19)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../didj.shtml">author bio</a>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/3.png" width="118" height="178" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5: alt="3.png"/>The Ojai Valley Museum announced today that the âMad About Sergioâ reception is sold out.                         <h3 class="entry-header">MAD About Sergio: Anatomy of an Exhibit</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>From the Ojai Valley Museum - article by Denise Picard, photography by Ashley Conde/Brooks Institute.  Enjoy!</em></p>

<p><strong>Anatomy of an Exhibit</strong></p>

<p>What occurs behind the scenes building an exhibit? Obviously there is talent, but in addition there is a lot of work and passion.  Take for instance the current Ojai Valley Museum exhibit, âMAD About Sergio.â The seed was planted when Bobbie Boschan, Vice President of the Museum Board of Trustees met Sergio AragonÃ©s two years ago at the former location of Artful Living. He was taking knitting lessons so he could knit a scarf for his wife for Valentineâs Day. The following year, when Boschan saw the cover of the program for the Ojai Film Festival, created by AragonÃ©s, the seed sprouted into the idea of an exhibit.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/sergio06_AshleyConde_BrooksInstitute_web.jpg" width="300" height="201" alt="sergio06_AshleyConde_BrooksInstitute_web.jpg"/></p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Playwrights Conference Aug. 11-16</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>One of the reasons why I volunteer for the playwright's conference every year is that I get a chance to connect with old friends and colleagues and get reacquainted with a process I know all too well â the play workshop.  It is a process that maybe only interesting to theater geeks and professionals but it is fascinating and I get great pleasure in knowing that some of theater's most gifted minds come here to Ojai to workshop their new creations and prepare them for the Great White Way.  Some great minds have assembled for the 12th season of the Ojai Playwright's Conference and last night I made a surprise visit on one of those old friends.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">August 11, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003076"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3076">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">4-H Kids and Their Animals: the Ultimate Betrayal at the Fair</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>Guest Editorial by Marty Fast, a former 4-H leader who lives in Ojai</em></p>

<p>Once again this year, the 4-H animals are on display at the Ventura County Fair. Many of these animals return home once the fair is over, but what happens to the pigs and other market animals? Market pigs begin their life with great pain and suffering. Procedures such as castration, tail docking and ear notching are all done with no painkillers or anesthesia.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/08/4h_kids_and_their_animals_the.shtml">Continue reading "4-H Kids and Their Animals: the Ultimate Betrayal at the Fair" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">August 04, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003058"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3058">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Teaching Yoga in the Ojai Valley </h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Teaching Yoga to the Elders of Ojai<br />
<a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/suz9.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/suz9.shtml', 'popup', 'width=1024,height=687,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0' ); return false">View image</a><br />
Ojai, California, 1972. <br />
<em>Suza and her first yoga teacher, Sarah Kirton, who is described in</em> Yoga for People Over 50, <em>(1977). </em></p>

<p>The first thing my 90-year old student asked me while she was on the floor stretching her legs was, "Do you have a boyfriend?"  "Oh my God," I thought, "It just never ends. Romance will always be more interesting  than the rest of life."<br />
 <br />
I like to pry into the lives of my students as much as they like to pry into mine. After forty years of teaching, in every setting and  every sort of circumstance, I can safely say that <em>nothing</em> is as it seems.  In the course of a typical month I make the rounds all over the valley, from  picture-perfect estates in Rancho Matilija, the top of Foothill, Thacher, McAndrew and high up Sulphur Mountain Road in Upper Ojai, to more modest homes in the hills of Krotona, to humble apartments and small family houses on the valley floor, and even old "shacks" that are falling apart and going back to the Earth. </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/08/teaching_yoga_in_the_ojai_vall.shtml">Continue reading "Teaching Yoga in the Ojai Valley " &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 09:26 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/08/teaching_yoga_in_the_ojai_vall.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/08/teaching_yoga_in_the_ojai_vall.shtml#comments">Comments (0)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../suza.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>

<p>One person wrote: "Suza thanks for sharing.... the back bends shown in your slideshow .. are they good for osteoporosis backs?" </p>

                     <a id="a003017"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3017">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai-Ventura International Film Festival Announces Historic Partnership with Brooks Institute</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>Submitted Press Release:</em></p>

<p><strong>Brooks Institute to Serve as Festivalâs First-Ever Ventura Venue; Hosting Screenings, Workshops, Panels and Special Events on Nov. 5 â 8, 2009 </strong></p>

<p>OJAI, CALIF. (July 21, 2009) â The <a href="http://www.ojai-venturafilmfestival.com">Ojai-Ventura International Film Festival</a>, formerly Ojai Film Festival, and Brooks Institute are proud to announce that the Institute will serve as the host for all Festival programming in Ventura as the event marks its 10th anniversary by expanding its footpint into the City of Ventura.  </p>

<p>Running from November 5 - 8, 2009, this milestone year will render opportunities for a broader regional and national audience to take part in a variety of Festival events at the Brooks Institute campus.  Formerly a motion picture studio, the Institute will host many of the Festivalâs screenings, the annual filmmaker party and all of the Festivalâs workshops and panels.  Additionally, Ventura Marriott has signed on as a hotel sponsor. Ojai continues to serve as the Festivalâs headquarters with screenings held at various Ojai venues.<br />
</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">July 22, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003015"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3015">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Otto Heino tribute</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>a nice post on Otto Heino by Janna over at <a href="http://www.conejopost.com/?p=520" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Conejo Post</a>.  short excerpt below...</p>

<blockquote>I felt like I was a friend of Otto Heino.  He was just that kind of person, who, if you met him a few times, you felt like  you knew him.  He was so greatly talented, but so friendly and natural too.  Otto lived and potted in the east end of Ojai, among the towering old oak trees, and near acres of orange orchards.  He had a gallery/store called The Pottery, in front of his home and studio, and it was open most afternoons, for anyone interested to wander through, either on the honor system, or with a friend helping out there.</blockquote>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Tyler Suchman at 07:53 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2009/07/otto_heino_tribute.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">July 17, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a003002"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-3002">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai's Famous Potter Otto Heino Has Passed Away at the age of 94</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>I used to stop on my daily walks and visit Otto at his home. He was such a friendly, talkative soul during the time I lived in the East End of Ojai. Would be fun to share some Otto memories or stories if anyone has them.  Here is the story in the Star.  <a href="http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2009/jul/17/otto-heino-ojai-artist-known-for-glaze-dies-at/">http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2009/jul/17/otto-heino-ojai-artist-known-for-glaze-dies-at/</a><strong><blockquote>âItâs the end of an era, really. Otto was truly one of the last great American craftsmen to live in our community,â said Donna Granata, founder of Focus on the Masters, a nonprofit educational organization that documents the lives and works of area artists.</p>

<p>âHe had a work ethic unmatched by anyone I know. This was a man who once produced a glaze to match a car,â Granata said of Heino, who was still using a pottery wheel and firing his own kilns into his 90s. âAll of his success, literally, he created with his two hands.â</blockquote></strong><br />
<blockquote><br />
<strong>New Info** Otto's La Times Obituary <a href="http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-otto-heino21-2009jul21,0,1590279.story">http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-otto-heino21-2009jul21,0,1590279.story</a></strong></blockquote></p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">July 13, 2009</h2>
                     <a id="a002990"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2990">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Broken Word Reading Series in Ojai</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/poetry_matters_in_ventura_and.shtml"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/shi.gif" width="72" height="72" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="Poetry Matters! " style="float: right; border: 0px; padding-left: 10px; padding-right: 10px; padding-bottom: 10px;" border="0" /></a><a href="http://ojaibrokenword.wordpress.com/">Broken Word Happy Hour</a> is a spoken word reading series featuring fiction and poetry writers from around Southern California. I had the pleasure of participating in <a href="http://www.robertpeake.com/archives/455-Broken-Word-at-The-Farmer-and-The-Cook.html">the second reading in this series</a> back in May, and am looking forward to reading again alongside talented local word-wielders at the fourth Broken Word happening on <strong>Thursday, July 23rd at 7PM</strong> at Ojai's own <a href="http://www.farmerandcook.com/"><strong>Farmer & Cook</strong></a>. </p>

<p>Come enjoy a summer evening on the patio, listening to stories and poems while enjoying Farmer & Cook's signature vegetarian snacks as well as organic beer and wine. Previous events have been a great success--and now the secret is out! For more information and directions, visit the newly launched <a href="http://ojaibrokenword.wordpress.com/">Broken Word website</a>.</p>
