                     <a id="a002186"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2186">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">World Affairs Council Presentation: When China Ruled the Seas, the Treasure Fleets of the Ming Dynasty 1405-1433</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/olympics-opening-ceremony-41507355.jpg" width="300" height="225" alt="olympics-opening-ceremony-41507355.jpg"/></p>

<p><strong>The World Affairs Council CA Central Coast Presents:<br />
When China Ruled the Seas, the Treasure Fleets of the Ming Dynasty 1405-1433. </strong></p>

<p>September 11, 2008 at the Ventura County Maritime Museum<br />
2731 S. Victoria Avenue<br />
Oxnard, CA 93035 <br />
5:30 p.m. -7:30 p.m.<br />
(Reception with appetizers and no-host bar 5:30-6:30, presentation 6:30-7:30) <br />
Cost: $15 members, $20 non-members </strong></p>

<p>During the Opening Ceremonies for the Olympics, China celebrated the achievements of the great navel fleets of the Ming Dynasty, events hardly known or recounted in the West.</p>

<p>By 1405 China had been a powerful empire for nearly two thousand years. The crown jewels of Emperor Zhu Diâs navy were his Treasure boats. These behemoths, nearly half the size of World War II aircraft carriers, were largest wooden sailing ships ever built. And although the wealth they carried back to China was staggering, it created conflict between the two factions that served the emperor; the Military and the Mandarin bureaucrats.</p>

<p>After the emperorâs death, the chief Mandarin sought to undermine the power of his foes by decreeing that the fleets be grounded, the records destroyed and overseas trade forbidden.  The result crippled China for the next 600 years - a decline that is only being reversed today as witnessed during the Olympics.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/09/world_affairs_council_presenta_1.shtml">Continue reading "World Affairs Council Presentation: When China Ruled the Seas, the Treasure Fleets of the Ming Dynasty 1405-1433" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Howard Smith at 08:45 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/09/world_affairs_council_presenta_1.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                  <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../howard.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                                          

                     <h2 class="date-header">August 30, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a002184"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2184">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">No More Nathan: Larramendy Gallery Closing?</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>I received this somewhat cryptic email today.  I always enjoyed walking by the gallery and checking out the latest exhibits.  Cassandra Jones' show was great, and the Men of Ojai Calendar launch party was a blast.  Best of luck to Nathan in his next incarnation.</em></p>

<p>Dear Friends,</p>

<p>As I move on to the next leg of my career in promoting the arts, I no longer feel that having a static "brick and mortar" space is essential to cultivating rich and innovative art experiences. My passion to provide opportunities for artists and the art community remains the same. Please stay tuned for future projects presented by Nathan Larramendy â it will only get better!</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/08/nathan-larramendy-gallery.shtml">Continue reading "No More Nathan: Larramendy Gallery Closing?" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Stop the Trucks: Sneaking Through Town on Grand Avenue???</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Grand%20Ave%20Trucks.JPG" width="400" height="205" alt="Grand Ave Trucks.JPG"/><br />
<strong><br />
Ray Smith of Daly Road Graphics sent us these notes and photographs about Gravel Trucks in which it appears that trucks coming and going from Santa Paula are driving on residential streets.  If true this would a clear violation of local road and traffic regulations.  While we await further confirmation, here is Ray's first person report: </strong></p>

<p><strong><em>" I spotted another truck near my home.  Apparently, they are coming from Santa Paula, but instead of going through downtown via Ojai Avenue, they cut north to Grand Avenue.  They head east, turn onto West Summer St., <br />
then south on Canada to pick up Ojai Avenue again.   This is the third time I've seen one do this. "</em></strong></p>

                     <a id="a002179"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2179">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Education Foundation: 2008 Garden of Knowledge</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/2008_GOKBook_transparent.jpg" width="200" height="161"  alt="Ojai Education Foundation: 2008 Garden of Knowledge" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" />The <a href="http://www.ojaief.org/" target="_blank">Ojai Education Foundation</a> hosts its third annual <a href="http://www.ojaief.org/GOK2008/GOK2008.htm" target="_blank">Garden of Knowledge</a> benefit <strong>Sept. 13, from 3:30 to 8 p.m., in the gardens of Marc and Julia Whitman in Ojai</strong>.</p>

<p>The event features gourmet food, art, music and entertainment.  Works by national and internationally acclaimed local artists will be auctioned; Nordhoff High School Dance Department students will perform and Matilija Junior High School science teachers will give a physics demonstration. </p>

<p>Some of Ojaiâs best-known artistsâ work will be sold in a silent auction. Artists include Gayel Childress, Bert Collins, Sherri Loehr, Elisse Pogofsky-Harris, Julia Pfeifer, Jeff Sojka, Bruce Tomkinson, Leslie Thompson, Elaine Unzicker and Nancy Whitman. Collectorsâ pieces will be raffled from Otto Heino, Ted Gall and Beatrice Wood. Artists Edward Morgan and James Menzel-Joseph will demonstrate the creative process during the event. OEF will also honor its Educational Hero of the year.</p>

<p>The cost is $100 per person, which includes a complimentary raffle ticket. Sponsorship opportunities are available.<br />
To purchase a ticket or request a sponsorship, call 805-669-3075, e-mail <a href="mailto:info@ojaief.org">info@ojaief.org</a> or log on to <a href="http://www.ojaief.org" target="_blank">www.ojaief.org</a>. The Ojai Education Foundation is a nonprofit organization that provides programs to benefit Ojai youths in public schools.</p>

We would like each candidate to share their thoughts with the public on the how they intend to deal with the long term threat posed by gravel trucking through Ojai and the blind eye that the Ventura County Planning Division is seemingly paying to regular daily violations of the existing Conditional Use Permits (C.U.P.'s). </strong><br />

Read on to find out a bit more about two of their volunteers and how you can get involved.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Judy-Mercer-Richard-Hoye.jpg" width="450" height="322" alt="Judy Mercer Richard Hoye"/></p>

<p>The picture is of Judy Mercer and Richard Hoye, volunteers in the Collections department of the Museum.  They are holding an antique Kellog telephone that was a gift to the museum from Bettie Pente of Ojai in 1987. It is one of hundreds of interesting items housed in the Museum's Collections.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">August 13, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a002153"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2153">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">April Hendrix to Debut New Band, New Sound</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/April%20Hendrix%20Flyer%20v1.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/April%20Hendrix%20Flyer%20v1.shtml', 'popup', 'width=480,height=622,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0' ); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/April%20Hendrix%20Flyer%20v1-thumb.jpg" width="180" height="233" alt="April Hendrix Flyer v1.jpg" align="left" hspace="5"/></a></p>

<p>April Hendrix, Ojaiâs own soul star, will debut her new band and original songs on <b>Sunday, August 24, beginning at 6:30 PM at The Farmer & the Cook, 339 W. El Roblar Drive in Meiners Oaks</b>. Well known around the county and beyond as the lead singer for blues outfit Baby Sister and soul/funk band Soul Star Express, April is forging ahead with a brand new sound combining elements of soul, blues, rock, funk and hip hop. She has been hard at work writing songs with partners from across the musical spectrum and now has assembled a smoking hot band to deliver her sound to the world.<br />
  <br />
Anchored by bassist Aron Von Alstine and drummer Greg Weiser, her band includes local favorites Sunny Erickson on guitar and David Gorospe on keys, both members of the popular funk groove band Euphoria.<br />
  <br />
The daughter of a professional backup singer, April Hendrix comes from a strong musical lineage. Besides her famous cousin Jimi, her uncles âSpudâ and Jerome Hendrix were stalwarts of many Ventura county bands. Often traveling with her mother on the road, Aprilâs earliest memories of performing are in the backseat of the car, singing along with her motherâs demo tapes. But Sharon âMuffyâ Hendrix made her daughter promise she would get an education before she pursued a music career. So April found a way to do both.</p>

                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/08/april_hendrix_to_debut_new_ban.shtml">Continue reading "April Hendrix to Debut New Band, New Sound" &raquo;</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">August 05, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a002140"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2140">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">World Affairs Council Presentation</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/05.JPG" width="300" height="290" alt="05.JPG"/><br />
<strong><br />
World Affairs Council CA Central Coast</p>

<p>When China Ruled the Seas, the Treasure Fleets of the Ming Dynasty 1405-1433. </p>

<p>Speaker: Howard Smith </p>

<p>September 11, 2008 <br />
Location: Ventura County Maritime Museum<br />
2731 S. Victoria Avenue<br />
Oxnard, CA 93035 <br />
Time: 5:30 p.m. -7:30 p.m.<br />
(Reception with appetizers <br />
and no-host bar 5:30-6:30, <br />
presentation 6:30-7:30) <br />
Cost: $15 members, $20 non-members </strong></p>

<p>By 1405 China had been a powerful empire for nearly two thousand years. The crown jewels of Emperor Zhu Diâs navy were his Treasure boats. These behemoths, nearly half the size of World War II aircraft carriers, were largest wooden sailing ships ever built. And although the wealth they carried back to China was staggering, it created conflict between the two factions that served the emperor; the Military and the Mandarin bureaucrats.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/08/world_affairs_council_presenta.shtml">Continue reading "World Affairs Council Presentation" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Howard Smith at 08:40 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/08/world_affairs_council_presenta.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                  <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../howard.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Guest Editorial: Elin Suleymanov, Consul General of Azerbaijan</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>Back in May, a <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/05/sufi-music-azerbaijan.shtml">free music event</a> was held at Matilija Auditorium and Glen Muse, featuring Mugham, the classical music of Azerbaijan.   The <a href="http://www.azconsulatela.org/" target="_blank">Consul General of Azerbaijan</a>, Elin Suleymanov, has written a story that looks back upon their visit.  Check it out, its a great read.</em></p>

<p><strong>Bringing Azerbaijani Mugham to Ojai</strong><br />
By Elin Suleymanov</p>

<p>When I first visited Ojai it reminded me of the Caucasus Mountains of my home- Azerbaijan. Perhaps, this almost nostalgic feeling made coming back to Ojai inevitable. Moreover, when planning California concerts of Mugham, the most spiritual part of Azerbaijanâs musical heritage, a performance in Ojai seemed an obvious choice. After all, what could a better place for a concert of the music strongly influenced by Sufism than a community so familiar with spiritual teachings?</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/06/azerbaijan-elin-suleymanov.shtml">Continue reading "Guest Editorial: Elin Suleymanov, Consul General of Azerbaijan" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">June 17, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a002046"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2046">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Jen To Strike Again!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>This is just in from the NY Times website:</strong></p>

<p>June 17, 2008<br />
Oregon woman plans to parade topless on July 4 <br />
By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS<br />
Filed at 6:51 p.m. ET</p>

<p>ASHLAND, Ore. (AP) -- A woman seen frequently in Ashland riding topless on her bicycle says she plans to be in Ashland's Fourth of July parade free and independent of all clothing but a hemp G-string. The Chamber of Commerce says that's contrary to the rules for the family celebration. She says she'll sue if she can't parade as she wishes.</p>

<p>Jen Moss has been known as ''The Naked Lady'' since she moved to Ashland in May from Ojai, Calif., drawn by the town's nudity laws. They specify only that people must cover their genitalia in a city park or the downtown commercial district, which means Moss need not cover her breasts.</p>

<p>The police in California, she says, harassed her when she rode her bicycle wearing a G-string and pasties.</p>

<p>Moss applied for an entry for the parade, which draws thousands each year.</p>

<p>The Ashland Chamber of Commerce learned of her coverage plans from an online posting. She promised to lead in-line skaters ''wearing only a hemp G-string and blowing a conch shell.''</p>

<p>''We don't feel that someone in the parade who is topless or nearly naked is appropriate for a family audience,'' said parade chairman James Kidd.</p>

                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/06/jen_to_strike_again.shtml">Continue reading "Jen To Strike Again!" &raquo;</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">June 10, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a002033"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2033">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">The Confessions of Cassandra</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The Ojai Music Festival is known for its adventurous spirit, for its lust for risk -- musically speaking. </p>

<p>In turn, Libbey Bowl audiences are known for their patience, and often they are rewarded with the&nbsp; unforgettable. When Steve Reich's difficult &quot;Four Organs&quot; was premiered in New York in the early l970's, a near-riot erupted. When played for the first time on the west coast In Ojai in the same era, the piece piqued interest and resulted in a recording (according to a <a href="http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/arts/la-et-ojai10-2008jun10,0,7294146.story">story</a> recounted by Mark Swed in today's <em>Los Angeles Times</em>.) </p>

<p>Last Saturday night at Libbey Bowl the festival broke away from its celebration of the hypnotic music of&nbsp; Reich for an exploration into the outer limits of voice and music today. The evening began with a baffling piece in which one woman alone sang wordlessly against an array of electronica without a beat. </p>

<p>But what followed was something else.</p>

<p>Mesmerizingly so. </p>

<p>Described as a &quot;spoken opera&quot; by composer Michael Jarrell, &quot;Cassandre&quot; is actually a monologue with orchestral support, but most of all it's a stunning piece of writing, drawn from the ancient myth of Cassandra, as written by one of the greatest of German writers today, the novelist <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christa_Wolf">Christa Wolf</a>. </p>

<p>Barbara Sukowa, a compelling actress with a guttural voice, growled her way through an English translation of the monologue. This was the West Coast premiere of the piece. Here's how it begins: 

<p>Cassandra is a ruined woman. Once she was a princess, but now she has been brought low by a god.Because she refused Apollo, he spit into her mouth, and forever after she was cursed to speak the truth to all, but be believed by no one. <br /> </p></p>

<p>&quot;Sounds like the Al Gore story,&quot; said one fellow in my section.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/06/the_confessions_of_cassandra.shtml">Continue reading "The Confessions of Cassandra" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Kit Stolz at 10:51 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/06/the_confessions_of_cassandra.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/06/the_confessions_of_cassandra.shtml#comments">Comments (3)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../kit.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>

                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2028">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Wine Festival 2008</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>As the major annual fundraiser for the <a href="http://www.rotaryojaiwest.org/">Rotary Club of Ojai West</a>, empowering them to donate over $20,000 annually to our community and charities around our nation and world, the <a href="http://www.ojaiwinefestival.com">Ojai Wine Festival</a> is quite an event.  This year was the Festival's 21st year, featuring at least 38 wineries...ALL from California and MANY very local (there are microbreweries too!)</p>

<p>My wife and i first attended in 2005, to celebrate our near-to-the-date first wedding anniversary.  We brought friends, cheese, and crackers...and made a tradition. </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">May 29, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a002010"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-2010">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">My Memorial Day 2008</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Many of you may remember when i last attended the Memorial Day events here in the Ojai Valley in 2006, after which i wrote <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/05/my_memorial_day_in_ojai.shtml">this report</a> which brought up issues of patriotism, accountability, veteran-civilian relations, and the meaning of supporting the troops while opposing the war.</p>

<p>This year's Memorial Day was quite different for me, but not so much because of the local events.  i have made some significant personal strides relative to the above issues by listening to the testimony of warriors at the Winter Soldier 2008 event, responding to my brother's choice to join the Marine Corps Reserves, reading some of the local veterans' stories in their book "Ojai Valley's Veterans Stories", and connecting to local organizers of Iraq Veterans Against the War.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>At this time in 2006 i didn't have a nine-month-old daughter, so i was a little slower getting out the door this time.  i missed the pancake breakfast at the American Legion building in Oak View, but caught the last half of the parade, where i noted several violations of the <a href="http://usinfo.state.gov/russki/infousa/facts/flag_code.htm">Federal Flag Code</a>.  After the parade a sizable crowd gathered at Longhorn's Feed & Supply to hear speakers and for the awarding of the parade trophies.   i approached as Ms. Shelley Rhoades was reading the same poem she read last time in Libbey Park, while Boy Scout Troop 503 did the same enigmatic flag-passing ceremony.  i began to wonder what was going to happen at the park.<br />
Some guy took the "stage" and led us all in prayer to a Christian God, thanking him for our community and lifestyle and for helping us preserve it, in Jesus' name.  Veteran Al Wescott sang his original song "Soldiers, Sailors, and Tired Old Men", just like he did in 2006.  The teen girls in their long satin dresses and label-sashes gave out awards to everything from a bagpiper to a llama (although i think it was an alpaca, technically) to "pooper scoopers".  People clapped and cheered, then left.  </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/05/my_memorial_day_2008.shtml">Continue reading "My Memorial Day 2008" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 02:31 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/05/my_memorial_day_2008.shtml">Permalink</a>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Memorial Day 2008</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>from the <a href="http://www.vfwojaivalley.com/index1.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Ojai Valley VFW</a>...</em></p>

<p>On <strong>Monday May 26th</strong>, the VFW of Ojai will be having a Memorial Day Service/Program at Libby Bowl. The program is from 12 noon until 2:30pm. The United State Air Force Band from Vandenberg Air Force Base will be performing. There will also be Army memorabilia and vehicles, Wall of Remembrance, Patriotic Singers: Richard Lyons & Ellen Johnson, and Veteran Speakers. It is being sponsored by Rabobank, The Ojai Lions Club, Ojai American Legion, The United States Army, Rotary Club of Ojai-West, and the Ojai American Legion Women's Auxiliary. There will also be a free breakfast for veterans at the American Legion Hall in Ojai that day from 7am to 10am. For questions or more information, call Capp Loughboro at 642-0241.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">May 21, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001994"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1994">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Stop The Trucks: Praise for Ojai in the Press</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/CIMG3439a.JPG" width="400" height="253" alt="CIMG3439a.JPG"/></p>

<p><em>Photo courtesy of Daly Road Graphics & Ray Smith</em></p>

<p><strong>On involvement<br />
If you're going to complain, get involved </p>

<p>From Bill Lascher, Editor of the Ventura Reporter:</strong></p>

<p>"As has been groused about numerous times on these pages and society in general, too many people whine about the actions taken by government and other institutions without ever taking action to challenge those institutions. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Some lament in Ventura County that red tape and not-in-my-backyard-minded activists hinder progress. Yet, without a vigilant active community little would be done to help the vast majority of our citizens, many decisions would be taken with myopic profit motives and few socially minded initiatives would get off the ground...."</p>

<p> </p>

<p>"...Now, the first signs are emerging of other successes by local activists, even as new fights take shape...."</p>

<p> </p>

<p>"...Ojai residents concerned about mining truck traffic along Route 33 have scored something of a victory and will have a chance to ensure that victory holds May 14. That day, the Santa Barbara County Planning Commission will consider final action on the proposed Diamond Rock mine. After criticism of the mine's plans to use Highway 33 to transport material and other environmental concerns that might impact Ventura County more than Santa Barbara County, the plan was altered to prevent trucks from traveling south on 33, to reduce its production rates and truck trips to avoid situations where those truck trips might be necessary, and to address other environmental concerns. It is a testament to the continued involvement and dedication of Ojai and Cuyama Valley residents - as well as the mine owner's willingness to discuss community concerns - that such progress was made..."</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/05/stop_the_trucks_praise_for_oja.shtml">Continue reading "Stop The Trucks: Praise for Ojai in the Press" &raquo;</a>

                     <a id="a001993"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1993">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Libbey Bowl makeover</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The Ojai Music Festival is leading the way in a $3 million Libbey Bowl renovation.  Based on an <a href="http://ojaivalleynews.blogspot.com/2008/05/libbey-bowl-to-get-3m-makeover.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OVN article</a>, it appears that the bowl is a tear-down, with a working 2010 timeline.  </p>

<blockquote>Both [Ojai Music Festival executive director Jeff] Haydon and [architect and former mayor David] Bury expressed confidence in the 2010 time line for the project. "We are hoping the design process will take about a year," Bury said. The construction company Jones and Jones will be doing the dismantle and rebuild, which is expected to take from eight to 12 months after the bureaucratic process is complete.  "Culturally and historically, this is a really important project and some people want to be involved just because of that," said Bury, "so I think we will get a lot of advice from the experts."</blockquote>

                     <h2 class="date-header">May 10, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001971"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1971">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Suï¬ Music of Azerbaijan</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>This free music event, hosted and funded by the Consulate General of Azerbaijan in LA, looks really interesting. </em></p>

<p>Mugham, the classical music of Azerbaijan, is usually a suite with poetry and instrumental interludes. The sung poetry sometimes includes tahrir segments, which use a form of throat singing similar to yodelling. The poetry is typically about divine love and is most often linked to Sufi Islam. In contrast to the mugham traditions of Central Asian countries, Azeri mugham is more free-form and less rigid; it is often compared to the improvised field of jazz.  </p>

<p>Tuesday, May 13, 2008 <br />
6.30 â 8.00 p.m.<br />
FREE<br />
Location: Matilija Auditorium<br />
 703 El Paseo Rd. Ojai, CA 93023<br />
</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Tyler Suchman at 09:07 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/05/sufi-music-azerbaijan.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/05/sufi-music-azerbaijan.shtml#comments">Comments (3)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../tyler.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">May 02, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001954"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1954">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Libbey Bowl Survey</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>As you may know, Libbey Bowl is aging and in need of repairs or even rebuilding.  Following is a survey created by the Ojai Music Festival to give needed input on Libbey Bowl as they help the City of Ojai compile information it needs in rebuilding Libbey Bowl. There is information about the status of the Bowl, vision for moving forward, a request for your input, and an invitation to attend a meeting included in this survey.  The survey responses will be compiled after Sunday, May 13th.</p>

<p>Take the <a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/s.aspx?sm=BpFjn_2bN64FQ1bxo_2bV2DmkQ_3d_3d" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Libbey Bowl Survey</a> here.</p>

<p>My fondest Libbey Bowl memory is actually from before we moved here.  We were camping in Wheeler Gorge for a couple nights, and came into town to watch a movie being shown in Libbey Bowl.  We sat on the benches, looking up through the magnificent oaks, where Mars was at is closest point to the earth and shone through, between the branches of the tree.  Magical moments like that make Ojai one of the greatest places in the world.</p>

                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Tyler Suchman at 07:20 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/05/ojai-libbey-bowl-survey.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">April 20, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001927"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1927">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Shut Up and Be Happy! Music Video is a Finalist In The International Student Film Festival</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The following is a "link" of an explanation of Why and How the music video  "Shut Up and Be Happy" was made (featuring some Ojai Locals).  It's a short 3min film of the film maker, Dvorah Adler talking to the judges and voting audience about the film. <br />
<a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c8pks8v3iiM">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c8pks8v3iiM</a></p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">April 17, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001924"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1924">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Life After Taxes</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojainews.com/" target="_blank"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/ojai-news-editors-journal-1.gif" width="450" align="left" height="34" border="0" alt="daily ojai news" /></a><br /><br /></p>

<p>There <em>is</em> life after taxes (even though <a href="http://www.ojainews.com/nuclear_taxes08.pdf">said taxes are funding the estimated $3 trillion war bill and and annual $54 billion in nuclear weapons</a>, which are all about Death), and in the Valley of Plenty, there's lots of living to be done:</p>

<p>Tomorrow (Friday April 18th, 2008) sees <a href="http://www.ojaievents.com/event-detail.aspx?ID=2327">parents socializing about their joys and challenges</a> and Besant Hill School students <a href="http://www.ojaievents.com/event-detail.aspx?ID=2321">performing Broadway's 27th longest running musical</a>.  The long-fenced Wetlands Project between Nordhoff High and Meiners Oaks is <a href="http://ojaivalleynews.blogspot.com/2008/04/ojai-wetlands-project-opens-to-public.html">newly restored and open</a> once again to the public, and a rally and fundraising kickoff to <a href="http://www.ojaief.org/Save_Ojai_Schools_Flyer.htm">Save Ojai Schools</a> (from State budget cuts) will be held on Sunday April 20th at OUSD Headquarters.  An ongoing art exhibit titled "A Sense of Place" will feature the paintings of <a href="http://www.teganhope.com/">local artist Tegan Hope</a> at Busy Babes hair salon until May 31st, and the <a href="http://www.ojainews.com/2008/04/cc_agenda_042208.shtml">Ojai City Council will meet on Tuesday</a> the 22nd at 7:30pm.  That same evening, co-founder of <a href="http://www.afterdowningstreet.org/">afterdowningstreet.org</a>, David Swanson, will be <a href="http://ojaievents.com/event-detail.aspx?ID=2339">speaking at the Ojai Retreat</a> on strategies for saving our Constitution, Economy and Environment.</p>

<p>Just around the corner, the <a href="http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2008/apr/16/ojai-storytelling-festival-begins-with-a-free-on/">Ojai Storytelling Festival will open May 1st</a> in Libbey Bowl, and an organizational meeting for <a href="http://ojaivalleynews.blogspot.com/2008/04/locavore-group-forming-in-ojai.html">Ojai's new locavore group</a> is slated for May 10th (<a href="http://www.groups.google.com/group/eat-local-one-year">sign up here</a>).</p>

<p>Click on over to the <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com">Ojai Post</a> for current discussions of global warming, downed power lines, ending the war, illegal immigration, 9/11, childbirth, and more!</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">April 10, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001912"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1912">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">"Stop the Trucks:"  Expert cites problems in Ventura County's Resource Mangement Agency & Planning Division  </h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/4.jpg" width="400" height="259" alt="4.jpg"/></p>

<p><em>(photo courtesy of Daly Road Graphics & Ray Smith)</em></p>

<p>On Tuesday afternoon, April 8th, members of "Stop the Trucks" coalition successfully testified before the Ventura County Board of Supervisors at their regular weekly meeting after a presentation by consultant Tom Berg, who had been hired to assess issues and problems at the county's Resource Management Agency which includes the Planning Division.  </p>

<p>The Coalition stressed the need for monitoring and enforcement of permit conditions, particularly of gravel mine operations, a fact that was reflected back by four of the Supervisors to County staff at the end of the meeting.<br />
The Planning Division currently is responsible for oversight of the Conditional Use Permit (CUP) issued to the Ozena Mine and Gravel operation.</p>

<p>According to an article in the Ventura County Star by Tony Biasotti on Wednesday, April 9, 2008, Berg's noted <em>that there are there are many ways in which the county could be more "transparent, predictable and accountable."<br />
And, " the system has some problems."  </em></p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 11, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001861"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1861">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Storytelling Festival Winner!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>...and only entrant, Raymond Powers, with this delightful entry...</p>

<p><em>It was Spring, yet I had lost that in my step. In my driveway lay a blue dragonfly, motionless and rigid like the brown earthbound autumn leaves. I picked up the winged one and placed it in my palm. So light, it's weight imperceptible in my hand. It seemed strange to have one born of flight, of air and river life, leave it's remains on an asphalt grave. A metaphor, my life in my hands. Breathing three times, gentle, warm, across the cross that lay so still. Then, a tremble, a tickle, a straight vertical ascension, above the treetops and out of sight. This is where the miraculous meets the mundane, and the future moves beyond our imagination.</em></p>

<p>Congrats, Raymond.  Please stay on the line and our producer will get your info and send you a package.</p>

                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1839">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Amy Arani at the Ventura Theater</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>I was lucky enough to catch local yoga teacher Amy Arani at the <a href="http://www.socalmusician.com">SoCal Musician</a> showcase at the Ventura Theater Friday night.  Amy plays piano and was backed by three Ojai musicians (Will Makiling on drums, <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/chrisfoley.shtml">Chris Foley</a> on guitar, Dave Anter on bass) for most of her set.  Amy's rich voice reminded me at times of Natalie Merchant, Cher, Sarah MacLachlan, Siouxie Sioux (remember the Banshees?) with a touch of Tori Amos.  </p>

<p>Comparisons aside, her voice is fantastic.  Amy will be graduating from UCSB in a couple of weeks and hopefully focusing more on her music.  Meantime you can visit her at <a href="http://www.myspace.com/amyarani ">http://www.myspace.com/amyarani </a>.  She's playing this Wednesday at the Experimental Cafe in Oxnard at 9:45pm.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 23, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001815"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1815">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Stop the Trucks: Highway 33 Bridge Collapses!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/images/over-pass-work2.pdf">over-pass-work2.pdf</a></p>

<p>In today's Ventura County Star:<br />
Saturday, February 23, 2008, from staff reports:</p>

<p><strong>Bridge on Highway 33 Collapses: No One Hurt</strong></p>

<p>A bridge support beam failure caused 130 to 150 feet of embankment along south-bound Highway 33 above Ojai to slide into the North Fork of Matilija Creek on Friday evening, authorities said.</p>

<p>The roadway was empty at the time of the collapse and no one was hurt, California Highway Patrol officials sad.</p>

<p>The bridge, located 10 to 12 miles north of Ojai, reportedly gave way about 6:15 p.m., according to the CHP.</p>

<p>Only southbound lanes were affected, officials said and northbound lanes remained open to residents and emergency personnel.</p>

<p><strong>For all other vehicles, the CHP expects a long-term closure of the highway between Lockwood Valley Road to the north and Matilija Road to the south.</strong></p>

<p>Caltrans crews worked to repair the roadway Friday night, authorities said.</p>

<p><br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/02/stop_the_trucks_highway_33_bri.shtml">Continue reading "Stop the Trucks: Highway 33 Bridge Collapses!" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 14, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001790"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1790">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Stop the Trucks: Complaint Against Ozena</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/truckstop.JPG" width="300" height="126" alt="truckstop.JPG"/></p>

<p>Christmas in Ojai from Daly Road Graphics </p>

<p><br />
<strong>On February 1, 2008 "Stop the Trucks," filed the following formal complaint against the Ozena Mine with the head of the Ventura County Planning Division, Kim Rodriguez:</strong></p>

<p>Please consider this letter on behalf of Ojai residents, John Broesamle, Howard Smith and the âStop the Trucksâ coalition a formal request to re-open the investigation of possible C.U.P violations on August 14, 2007 in the operation of gravel trucks in conjunction with the Ozena Valley Sand and Gravel Mine.</p>

<p>The Ojai âStop the Trucks Coalition is comprised of the City of Ojai; Forestwatch; the Ojai Valley Chamber of Commerce; the Ojai Valley School District; the Ojai Valley Board of Realtors; and many hundreds of private citizens.</p>

<p>In your  September 27, 2007 letter to Howard Smith (prepared by Pat Richards) and your January 8, 2008 letter to John Broesamle, the department denies both complaints of early morning and late afternoon CUP truck violations by citing the weigh tickets provided to the Planning Department by Ozena.  </p>

<p>After an extensive forensic study of the weigh tickets turned over to the Planning Division by the agent for Ozena, John Hecht of West Coast Environmental & Engineering, âStop the Trucks,â now firmly believes that the use of self-prepared weigh tickets, which appear to be the sole tool used by the division to monitor truck traffic, is not valid.  It is a method in which the results can seemingly be manipulated at will by the mine operator; and/or the weigh master; the trucking contractor; and/or their designated drivers; and may result in fraud or misrepresentation of the facts.  Clearly they fail the test as the evidentiary basis for any claims, pro or con.  </p>

<p>Details of our review are in the  âAnalysisâ provided both below and attached separately. <br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/02/stop_the_trucks_complaint_agai.shtml">Continue reading "Stop the Trucks: Complaint Against Ozena" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                     <a id="a001788"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1788">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Happy Valentine's Day! Favorite Love Songs?</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Happy-Valentine.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Happy-Valentine.shtml', 'popup', 'width=400,height=397,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0' ); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Happy-Valentine-thumb.jpg" width="180" height="179" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="Happy-Valentine.jpg"/></a>In honor of Valentine's Day, NPR recently shared their listeners' favorite love songs on their show, <a href="http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18950469">"All Songs Considered."</a>  There are a lot of interesting picks, some that I had never heard of - not your typical mainstream collection.  I can't believe Marvin Gaye's "Let's Get It On" didn't make the list.  And the one my husband and I love, The Smith's, "A Light That Never Goes Out," also didn't make the cut. What could be more romantic than these lyrics: "And if a double-decker bus/crashes in to us/to die by your side/is such a heavenly way to die./And if a ten-ton truck/kills the both of us/to die by your side/well, the pleasure, the privilege, is mine?"  Romantic, funny and sad all at once.</p>

<p>What's your favorite love song? What are you doing for V-day? Do you have a V-Day wish for anyone?</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 12, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001780"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1780">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Yoga in the Ojai Valley</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>Your Daily Yoga Vitamin: Supported Legs Up the Wall Pose</strong><br />
<img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/PicnikSmallEyebagSupporedLegsUpWallJHJacobs_060512_049_suza.jpg" width="291" height="408" alt="PicnikSmallEyebagSupporedLegsUpWallJHJacobs_060512_049_suza.jpg"/></p>

<p>During the course of a typical day, most people spend 16 hours with the head above the heart and the legs and pelvic area below the heart. Because of this, one of the first poses I teach students of all ages,  is "Legs Up the Wall Pose." <br />
 <br />
Supported Legs Up the Wall Pose (Viparita Karani in Sanskrit), known as Yogaâs Great Rejuvenator, is a gentle, inverted pose that can be practiced by almost everyone. It is a safe position that most people can hold long enough so that gravity can return the blood from the extremities to the vital organs.</p>

<p><strong>Inverted Poses:The Elixir of Life</strong></p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/02/yoga_in_the_ojai_valley.shtml">Continue reading "Yoga in the Ojai Valley" &raquo;</a>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Album Review: Jack Johnson's "Sleep Through The Static"</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/images/Jack_STTS.bmp" width="180" height="180" alt="Jack_STTS.bmp"/>  <a href="http://www.jackjohnsonmusic.com/home">Jack Johnson</a> lives in Hawai'i with his wife and kids, loves the natural world, and makes a brand of laid back, mostly acoustic rock that's popular in local surf communities like Santa Barbara and Ventura in addition to being highly palatable for nearly all radio-cafe-mall playing.  He also has been to Ojai to play Locally Grown 1.</p>

<p>Jack's fourth studio album, <em>Sleep Through The Static</em>, comes with this description:<br />
<blockquote>My friends and I have just finished recording a new album called Sleep Through the Static. At this point in my life I weigh about 190 lbs and my ear hairs are getting longer. I also have a couple of kids. My wife popped them out, but I helped. Some of the songs on this album are about making babies. Some of the songs are about raising them. Some of the songs are about the world that these children will grow up in; a world of war and love, and hate, and time and space. Some of the songs are about saying goodbye to people I love and will miss. <br />
</blockquote><br />
</p>

                     <a id="a001766"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1766">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Yoga In the Ojai Valley</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>Your Daily Yoga Vitamin -- Downward Facing Dog Pose</strong>  </p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/SmallHangingDogPose.jpg" width="450" alt="SmallHangingDogPose.jpg"/></p>

<p>The Downward-Facing Dog Pose, known in Sanskrit as <em>Adho Mukha Svanasana,</em> is named for the way dogs and other animals naturally stretch their bodies several times a day.  The shape of the pose resembles a dog stretching, with the arms and hands stretched out like a dogâs forepaws; the shoulders, spine and chest stretching; and the pelvis and tail bone high up in the air, stretching as far back away from the hands as possible. </p>

<p>When dogs stretch, they do so with great enjoyment--with all their heart and soul and a smile on their face! </p>

<p>Stretching daily in Downward-Facing Dog removes a lifetime of stiffness from the body and develops spinal strength and agility.<br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/02/yoga_in_the_ojai_valley_2.shtml">Continue reading "Yoga In the Ojai Valley" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 07:33 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/02/yoga_in_the_ojai_valley_2.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/02/yoga_in_the_ojai_valley_2.shtml#comments">Comments (12)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../suza.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 02, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001751"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1751">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Yoga in the Ojai Valley</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>Your Daily Yoga Vitamin -- the Yoga Splits</strong></p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Small%20JHJacobs_060609_055_suza.jpg" width="450" alt="yoga"/></p>

<p>For a larger view of this inspiring pose: <a href="http://www.suzafrancina.com/media/JHJacobs_060609_055_suza.jpg " target="_blank">http://www.suzafrancina.com/media/JHJacobs_060609_055_suza.jpg </a></p>

<p>This joyous, exhilarating pose is known in yoga as <em>Hanumanasana</em>, the Monkey Pose. When you practice this fabulous stretching pose, it feels--and looks like-- you are taking a giant leap!  This powerful stretch, with the arms reaching up toward the heavens represents a "leap in consciousness," a change from one stage of life to the next. The inspiring teacher demonstrating the pose is in her 70's. <em>Hanumanasana</em>  is a fun pose to practice at the end of your yoga session, when your body is nice and warmed up from practicing Standing Poses, Downward Facing Dog Pose, Lunges and other Yoga Basics. In the beginning, the pose can be practiced by placing a bolster and folded blankets under the hips and  pelvis. </p>

<p><em>Photo of Betty Eiler by Jim Jacobs.</em> </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 09:41 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/02/yoga_in_the_ojai_valley_3.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/02/yoga_in_the_ojai_valley_3.shtml#comments">Comments (4)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../suza.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <a id="a001738"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1738">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Homeless Art</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/taylor/homeless%20art.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/taylor/homeless%20art.shtml', 'popup', 'width=275,height=357,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0' ); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/taylor/homeless%20art-thumb.jpg" width="180" height="234" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="homeless art.jpg"/></a>Bob Ballard is doing great things for the homeless.  He is bringing them an opportunity to create.  And he is doing great things for art lovers.  He is bringing them art from an unlikely place: homeless shelters.  He is doing all of this because he wants to shift perceptions.</p>

<p>The story of Ballard's nonprofit, <a href="http://heartsoffire.tv/home.php">Hearts of Fire</a>, is in this weekâs <em>VC Reporter</em>.  Excerpt:</p>

<p><em>Hearts of Fire has become a burning passion for Ballard, who admits, âIâm not trying to solve any problems, not find them housing and food. Iâm just looking for a way for them to express themselves.â </p>

<p>His next project is to bring the art tour local and travel up and down the coast to the five counties suffering the brunt of homelessness. This year, he will focus on 25 shelters from Santa Barbara southward, with art workshops followed by local exhibits that can be attended by the artists themselves. </p>

<p>âWeâre just really excited about whatâs going to happen next,â he said. </em></p>

<p>This is only on newsstands until tomorrow, but you can always check it out <a href="http://vcreporter.com/article.php?id=5643&IssueNum=160">online</a> (but the newsstand version is better because you will get a better look at the featured artwork).</p>

<p>See the music video that inpired Ballard's work after the jump.</p>

                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/01/homeless_art.shtml">Continue reading "Homeless Art" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Lisa Snider at 11:00 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/01/homeless_art.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">January 28, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001737"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1737">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Soldiers Are Made To Die</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Heath_v_soldier.jpg" width="430" height="161" alt="Heath_v_soldier.jpg"/></p>

<p>Hollywood and fans the world over were shocked last week when Oscar-nominated actor Heath Ledger, gaining fame for challenging roles in films such as <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285742/">Monster's Ball</a>, <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0388795/">Brokeback Mountain</a>, and this coming summer's <a href="http://thedarkknight.warnerbros.com/">The Dark Knight</a>, was <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/01/22/heath.ledger.dead/index.html?eref=rss_topstories">found dead in his apartment</a> with sleeping pills nearby, at the age of 28.  </p>

<p>Lauded personally as a "down-to-earth, generous, kindhearted, life-loving, unselfish individual", his death prompted remarks from such Hollywood heavyweights as Mel Gibson and Ang Lee, both of whom mourned the "tragic loss" of a young life.</p>

<p>On the same day as Ledger's death, 20-year-old Army Sergeant Michael R. Sturdivant of Conway, Arkansas died in Kirkuk, Iraq "<a href="http://www.defenselink.mil/releases/release.aspx?releaseid=11636">of injuries sustained in a vehicle accident during convoy operations</a>".  Those who knew him praise his service-oriented attitude, dedication, and volunteerism.  His life was marked by a good heart and kind words.  Needless to say, Sturdivant's untimely and tragic death received <a href="http://www.legacy.com/saltlaketribune/gb/GuestbookView.aspx?PersonID=101811840">only local attention</a>.  </p>

<p>And why is this?  Is an actor's life worth more than a soldier's?  Is a tuxedo more prized than camouflage?  Many will unhesitatingly (although with some disgust) answer "Yes!", and it would seem that the evidence is on your side.  i answer "Yes" also, but not because i believe that one life or vocation is worth more than another.  i believe that Mr. Ledger's tragedy is so because it was UNEXPECTED.  The difference for Mr. Sturdivant is that  death is one of the accepted risks of his job.  Rarely mentioned or stated explicitly, to be killed is one of the things a soldier - and those who send him or her into battle - can EXPECT.  Soldiers are made to die, and war was made to kill them. </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/01/soldiers_are_made_to_die.shtml">Continue reading "Soldiers Are Made To Die" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 10:37 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/01/soldiers_are_made_to_die.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/01/soldiers_are_made_to_die.shtml#comments">Comments (23)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../evan.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                     </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">January 25, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001725"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1725">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Writing in Ojai on a rainy day.</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>A rainy day book review: Writing Begins with the Breath.</strong><br />
 <br />
These rainy days are great for writing! I've already gone through four pieces of Rudi's Organic Apple 'n Spice bread (not as good as Farmer and the Cook apple walnut muffins but good enough to fuel the brain) and, in between checking the Ojai Post, am actually getting some work done!<br />
 <br />
I am a self-taught writer. Almost forty years have flown by, but I still recall the day I triumphantly placed my first newspaper column, thick with white-out, on the desk of Fred Volz, the grand editor of the Ojai Valley News. Through sheer desperation and force of will, in the midst of taking care of my two-year old son Bo,  I managed to turn my messy pages into a sparkling published masterpiece --or so it looked to me! <br />
 <br />
A few weeks ago I found a book sitting on a chair near my front porch. When I saw the title, "Writing Begins with the Breath," for me, a yogi-writer, it was love at first sight! I thought to myself, "Wow! Just what I need!"  Destiny dropped this book in my lap just in the nick of time, as I am about to embark on a very personal writing adventure.<br />
 <br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/01/writing_in_ojai_on_a_rainy_day.shtml">Continue reading "Writing in Ojai on a rainy day." &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 09:41 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/01/writing_in_ojai_on_a_rainy_day.shtml">Permalink</a>

                              <p><em>Esteemed reader Lanny Kaufer sent me a release for this year's Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration with this note... "I have a special interest in this year's program. As a veteran of Dr. King's SCOPE project I registered "Negro" voters in rural Virginia in 1965-66. Through my association with King's organization, the SCLC, I met Deric Gilliard who lives in Atlanta and is a former Communications Director of the SCLC. By piecing together sponsors and speaking engagements at local schools, we (the Ojai Valley Youth Foundation and I) managed to entice him to come out here for a few days to share his first-hand knowledge of the Movement and many of the activists who embodied it."</em></p>

The rain location is the Chaparral Auditorium. </p>

<p>This yearâs theme is âWhere Do You Stand?â  Nearly every school in the Ojai Valley will be participating in this free community-wide program. This youth-led event, presented by the Ojai Valley Youth Foundation, will include art, music, and the spoken word in a festive setting with food and activities for every age.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">January 11, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001699"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1699">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Death of Bessie Smith at Zalk</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>I'd like to recommend that you go see the <a href="http://www.besanthill.org/news/?news_id=26">play "The Death of Bessie Smith"</a><a href="http://www.besanthill.org/news/?news_id=26"><img src="http://www.besanthill.org/images/pagebuilder_photos/hvsnews/eposter_bessie_smith-1.jpg" width="180" height="301" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt="Besant Hill School Zalk Theater" </a> by Edward Albee, at 8 p.m. tonight and tomorrow night only in Zalk Theater at Besant Hill School of Happy Valley in Upper Ojai. Admission is free. </p>

<p>Two of my favorite talents are in the production. My son Eli as Barney a friendly fellow with a flask who appears for a few moments at the beginning of the single-act, one hour tragedy. Local blues singer April Hendrix, my other favorite local talent, sways and sings in back-lit silhouette as the ghost of Bessie Smith. John Diehl brilliantly plays the irascible father of Alexis Poole, a young nurse whose starched white uniform contrasts beautifully with her pitch black soul.</p>

<p>Great dialog and a minimal, fabric-screen and wood frame set allow for a fun use of back-lighting and shadow play. Under the spirited direction of Scott Campbell, even the newest actors to the stage shine with star quality. Ivan Matip and Nachelle Sodetani both give outstanding stage-debut performances.</p>

<p>The school's office release from their website follows....</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">January 01, 2008</h2>
                     <a id="a001681"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1681">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Hope Frazier</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Hope Frazier died Saturday night at her home in Ojai. She was 60. Hope was diagnosed in April with an aggressive form of colon cancer. Even though I live only a few blocks from her house and walk past it regularly, I was not aware that she was struggling for her life.</p>

<p> I have many memories of Hope, who I met at a community gathering held at her house some years ago. I remember how she led me into her very funky art/writing studio  where she explained, among other things, that she didn't waste a single piece of paper. Every scrap had some creative recycled use. I remember purchasing a wall hanging made of rice paper with a photograph of Grandmother Oak, taken at sunset the day before the tree was taken down. Underneath the  image of Grandmother Oak was a poem called "Grandmother Oaks Last Pink Moment." <br />
(<em>After I first wrote this I learned that Hope's Grandmother Oak's Last Pink Moment monoprint, from a photograph made in Libbey Park, was the signature image of the Ojai Poetry Festival</em>)<br />
<a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/regional_2007.html#frazier">http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/regional_2007.html#frazier</a></p>

<p>This morning I felt inspired to visit Hope Frazier's website, a place that reflects Hope's magic and her love of the natural environment and all living things. I discovered so many things about her, that I know will inspire my own Life and creativity in the coming New Year. I hope you too will visit her site, if you have not done so already. <a href="http://www.HopeFrazier.com ">www.HopeFrazier.com </a></p>

<p>This morning friends of Hope received  the following e-mail message from her husband, Doug Adrianson, in which he shared some links to her obituaries. He wrote:</p>

<p> "Below are links to what is appearing today in the Miami Herald and Pasadena Star-News.  I'm sure the OVN will run something,  but not  until tomorrow. Please share these with the circle -- they may learn a few things about the old gal that they didn't know!"</p>

<p>  <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/511/story/363108.html">http://www.miamiherald.com/511/story/363108.html</a><br />
 <a href="http://www.pasadenastarnews.com/news/ci_7850468">http://www.pasadenastarnews.com/news/ci_7850468</a><br />
 <br />
<a href="http://www.insidesocal.com/publiceye/2007/12/hope_frazier_rip.html">http://www.insidesocal.com/publiceye/2007/12/hope_frazier_rip.html</a></p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">

                     <h2 class="date-header">December 07, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001627"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1627">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Theater 150 Gala Opening Tonight</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>As you may know, the former mortuary is <a href="http://www.theater150.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Theater 150</a>'s new home.  I'll assume they did some serious saging of the property. Tonight is the gala opening of their new play, Inspecting Carol.  Tickets are $50 per person. Performance begins at 8:00 p.m.  Check it out and support local theater.</p>

<p><u>Inspecting Carol</u><br />
A Christmas Carol meets The Government Inspector meets Noises Off in this hilarious alternative Christmas offering. A non-profit theater company rehearses A Christmas Carol, having dusted off this cash cow every season for nearly a generation. This year, though, their Dickensian money-maker will be thwarted by a stranger who might have the power to close their coffers for good. Everything goes wrong with their production, and hilarity is piled upon hilarity.</p>

                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Tyler Suchman at 12:57 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/12/theater-150-gala-opening.shtml">Permalink</a>

                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/FARM_8.5x11.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/FARM_8.5x11.shtml','popup','width=612,height=792,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0'); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/FARM_8.5x11-thumb.jpg" width="200" height="258" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></a></p>

<p>FARM presents âSPIRITED CHRISTMASâ CONCERT<br />
featuring JIMMY CALIRE and APRIL HENDRIX<br />
DECEMBER 8, 2007</p>

<p>Foundation of American Roots Music (FARM), the non-profit organization behind Ojaiâs famed Bowlful of Blues, will host a fundraising concert in the Ojai Art Center gallery on Saturday, December 8th beginning at 8 p.m. The evening, entitled âSpirited Christmas,â will feature the Jimmy Calire Quartet playing jazz arrangements of Christmas standards from his album of the same name followed by a holiday-themed blues dance with special guest vocalist April Hendrix.</p>

<p>FARM, under the direction of blues impresario Michael Kaufer, hopes to bring back the Bowlful of Blues in the fall of â08. The group also plans to reinstate its Roots Music-in-the-Schools programs that have reached many Ventura County children over the 20-plus years of the festivalâs history. All proceeds from the December 8 event will be applied toward those goals.</p>

<p>Holiday appetizers and an open bar will be available. Admission is $20 per person. Tickets are now on sale at Cardinali Brothers Music, 139 W. El Roblar Dr., Meiners Oaks; Ojai Creates, 606 E. Ojai Ave.;  and Ojai House, 304 N. Montgomery St., Ojai. Any remaining tickets will be available at the door. <br />
  <br />
Businesses are encouraged to reserve blocks of seats early for holiday staff parties by calling FARMâs information line at 646-7230. For more information, go to <a href="http://www.bowlfulofblues.com">www.bowlfulofblues.com</a>.</p>

<p> Bowlful of Blues staff and supporters invite the community to bring in the holiday season in a swinging fashion while helping FARM bring back Ojaiâs own Bowlful of Blues!<br />

<p>Saturday, November 3rd , 8:00pm, Sacred Space Studio, 410 Bryant Circle Suite A</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">October 24, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001546"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1546">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Faux News blames Al Qaeda for California Wildfires</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>From <a href="http://thinkprogress.org/2007/10/24/fox-news-al-qaeda-is-causing-the-ca-wildires/">Think Progress</a>:<br />
This morning on Fox News, hosts of the show Fox and Friends blamed the wildfires in California on a new culprit: al Qaeda. They pointed to a <strong>2003 FBI memo</strong>, which raised the possibility that al Qaeda may try to set wildfires around the western United States. They also noted that men in a âhovering helicopterâ saw âa guy starting one of these fires.â<br />
Later in the segment, host Steve Doocy acknowledged that in memo, al Qaeda <strong>didnât even mention California</strong>. âThey mention Colorado, Montana, Utah, and Wyoming,â he added.  (emphasis mine)</p>

<p><a href="http://thinkprogress.org/2007/10/24/fox-news-al-qaeda-is-causing-the-ca-wildires/">Watch it and read the transcript</a>.</p>

<p>i guess the whole "fight 'em over there so we don't have to fight 'em over here" thing didnt work out so well.  Bring the troops home to fight Al Qaeda's fires!  is "fear-mongering" one word, or two?</p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">a note on the Ojai Film Festival</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>from a reader / festival attendee...</em></p>

<p>This past weekend, we were privileged to attend the <a href="http://www.ojaifilmfestival.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Ojai Film Festival</a>. We are producers of the movie <a href="http://www.agendathemovie.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">AGENDA</a> featuring John Bennett Perry. This festival stands above all festivals we have ever attended. It is not only a splendid area for such an occasion but the residents of Ojai really raise the festival to a level that no other festival could possibly obtain.<br />
 <br />
Congratulations to Executive Director Laurie Kirby on her outstanding work as well as the supporting staff and festival Boards. Laurie is a great representative and did a superb job in the short time she has been in Ojai.<br />
 <br />
We look forward to visiting your area again. Once again congratulations Ojai!<br />
 <br />
Frank Jones<br />
Vikki Morvan-Jones</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">October 04, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001498"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1498">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Jackson Browne in Ojai: For the Birds III</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/jacksoneagle1.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/jacksoneagle1.shtml','popup','width=648,height=472,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0'); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/jacksoneagle-thumb.jpg" width="300" height="218" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></a></p>

<p><a href="http://www.jacksonbrowne.com/">Jackson Browne</a>, called the "poster boy of the Southern California confessional singer-songwriter movement of the late 1960s and early 1970s" by <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_Browne">Wikipedia</a>, will play a special benefit concert on <strong>Sunday October 7th at 1pm in Libbey Bowl</strong>, to benefit the <a href="http://www.ojairaptorcenter.org/">Ojai Raptor Center</a>.  </p>

<p>The concert also features local acoustic pop sensations <a href="http://www.householdgods.com/">The Household Gods</a>.  Open lawn seating tickets are $40, and are available at <a href="http://www.ojaibooks.com/">Local Hero Books</a> (formerly Table of Contents) in Ojai, and at Patagonia and Salzers in Ventura.</p>

<p>The Ojai Raptor Center is dedicated to the rehabilitation and release of orphaned and injured birds of prey and to providing educational programs to teach about raptors and our shared environment. They are a non  profit organization licensed by The California Department of Fish and Game and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The center takes in approximately 1,000 birds a year.  ~ Your ticket purchase is tax-deductible to the full extent of the law. ~</p>

<p>Jackson has played locally many times, notably for the Ventura Hillsides benefits.  Songs you may recognize include "Doctor My Eyes", "The Pretender", "Running On Empty", "Somebody's Baby", and "Lives In The Balance".</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 09:18 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/10/jackson_browne_in_ojai_for_the.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/10/jackson_browne_in_ojai_for_the.shtml#comments">Comments (5)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../evan.shtml">author bio</a>
