                     <h2 class="date-header">September 29, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001483"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1483">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">In Times of War: Ray Parker's Story</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/FilmFest_PReviewLogo.jpg" width="376" height="54" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></p>

<p>"<em>WW II veterans</em>", the letter accompanying the DVD tells me, "<em>are dying at a rate of over 2,000 every day, and we feel it is very important to get their personal stories before they are lost to us forever.</em>"  This film is one of those stories, and will be playing next friday as part of the Ojai Film Festival.</p>

<p>now, i'm not an objective reviewer...so i think it's important to describe the lens through which i'm seeing this: i'm 27 turns around the sun, and my Pearl Harbor was the World Trade Center.  i'm also a peace activist and i believe as Benjamin Franklin did: that there never was a good war (or a bad peace).  the whole "just" or "necessary" war thing is frankly lost on me.  when i read the film's description, which describes the "incredible journey" of the 18-year-old Parker who enlisted to "serve his country and fight the forces of evil" and shares his "hope, fear, and unrelenting courage", i became cynically prepared for a Sousa-march-littered tale of romanticized war.  Twenty-eight minutes later, i was teary-eyed.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/09/in_times_of_war_ray_parkers_st.shtml">Continue reading "In Times of War: Ray Parker's Story" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 01:35 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/09/in_times_of_war_ray_parkers_st.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/09/in_times_of_war_ray_parkers_st.shtml#comments">Comments (60)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../evan.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">September 27, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001481"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1481">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">All Politics Is Local</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong><em>Or: As Ojai Goes, So Goes The World</em></strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.ojainews.com/" target="_blank"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/ojai-news-editors-journal-1.gif" width="450" align="left" height="34" border="0" alt="daily ojai news" /></a><br /><br /></p>

<p>The Ojai Valley News reports that a potentially <a href="http://ojaivalleynews.blogspot.com/2007/09/man-arrested-on-assault-charge.html">gang-related vandalism and assault incident</a> took place on Tuesday on Santa Ana Road in Oak View, resulting in one arrest.</p>

<p>This comes on the heels of the Ojai Valley community's first major <a href="http://internationaldayofpeace.org/">International Peace Day</a> celebration, convened by the Retreats of Ojai, the Ojai Peace Coalition, and the Ojai Interfaith Alliance and titled "<a href="http://www.livingpeaceinojai.com">Living Peace in Ojai</a>".  The weekend-long event included the awarding of the first-ever <em>Noble Peace Prize</em> to <a href="http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2007/sep/20/couple-to-be-honored-at-peace-rally/">local activists Clive and Marion Leeman</a>, performance of the nation-traveling play "The Gift of Peace" which explores and urges support for the creation of a U.S. Department of Peace, and a well-attended and inspirational <a href="http://ojaivalleynews.blogspot.com/2007/09/ojai-joins-pursuit-of-peace.html">interspiritual gathering</a>.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.thepeacealliance.org/">The Peace Alliance</a>'s campaign to establish a Cabinet-level Department of Peace - which holds "<em>Effectively treat and dismantle gang psychology</em>" as one of its foundational efforts - is led by Ohio Congressman and <a href="http://www.dennis4president.com/home/">Presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich</a>, who was <a href="http://ojaivalleynews.blogspot.com/2007/09/kucinichs-presidential-quest-runs.html">in Ojai over the weekend</a> for two appearances.  <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/09/dennis_and_elizabeth_kucinich.shtml">At the Ojai Retreat</a> on Sunday afternoon, Dennis outlined his philosophy of "Strength Through Peace" to over 100 local supporters.  Later that evening at the Glen Muse estate on Libbey Ave, a more informal gathering left many feeling uplifted and hopeful for the Kucinich's new post-election home.</p>

<p>MORE after the jump!</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/09/all_politics_is_local.shtml">Continue reading "All Politics Is Local" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 04:51 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/09/all_politics_is_local.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/09/all_politics_is_local.shtml#comments">Comments (20)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../evan.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">September 21, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001472"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1472">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Happy International Peace Day!!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Good morning, and happy IPD!  Keeping an eye on the weather, here's what's in store:</p>

<p><strong>6-7pm</strong>: Vigil for Peace under the Pergola in front of Libbey Park.  Consider wearing white.</p>

<p><strong>7pm</strong>: Opening ceremony for the Living Peace in Ojai weekend, taking place in the fountain area of Libbey Park.  Music will gather and focus us, Judy Gabriel of Meditation Mount will welcome us, and Rae Hanstad of the Ojai City Council will read the Peace Day proclamation that the City issued last week.  Then the Ojai Peace Coalition will present its first-ever Noble Peace Prize to Clive and Marion Leeman of the peace vigil!  A prayer of Peace and some candle-lit silence will transition us to...<br />
<strong><br />
8:15pm</strong>: free screening of "Peace One Day" taking place on the patio at Ojai House, 304 N Montgomery St.  It's about four blocks from the Park, so as long as you're dressed warmly you're welcome and encouraged to create a candle-lit procession to get there.  The film is 80 minutes long.</p>

<p>if you're suddenly inspired to volunteer for any bit of this weekend, please call 805-715-9796 or <a href="mailto:info@livingpeaceinojai.com">email the team</a>.</p>

<p>* <em>if it's raining, the entire operation will move to the Chaparral auditorium, on Ojai Avenue at Fox Street </em>*</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 07:41 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/09/happy_international_peace_day.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                  <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../evan.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>

   - Food and Agriculture Committee will meet Sept. 20 at 7 p.m. at the old Honor Farm, a.k.a. new Help of Ojai West Campus on Baldwin Road.<br />

                     <h2 class="date-header">September 08, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001452"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1452">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Living Peace in Ojai!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Button.jpg" width="200" height="208" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></p>

<p><br />
In celebration of the <a href="http://www.un.org/events/peaceday/2006/index.shtml">United Nations' International Peace Day</a>, the Ojai Valley community presents a weekend of special events from Friday September 21 through Sunday September 23 entitled <em><a href="http://www.livingpeaceinojai.com">Living Peace in Ojai</a></em>!</p>

<p>Convened by the <a href="http://www.retreatsofojai.org">Retreats of Ojai</a>, the <a href="mailto:superher0@sbcglobal.net">Ojai Peace Coalition</a>, the Ojai Interfaith Alliance,  various yoga centers, and many other volunteers, and underwritten by <a href="http://casabarranca.com/">Casa Barranca</a> and Glen Muse, the <em><a href="http://www.livingpeaceinojai.com">Living Peace in Ojai</a></em> weekend is a coming together and celebration of our oneness, to explore and exemplify how we can activate and express Living Peace in ourselves and in our beautiful community every day, to help heal our fragile world.</p>

<p>If you would like to help in any way, please email <a href="mailto:info@livingpeaceinojai.com">info@livingpeaceinojai.com</a> or call 805.715.7976!</p>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Global Warming & Time/Warner Cable!!!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/DCP_5539.JPG" width="236" height="356" align="center" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></p>

<p><br />
For those of you also suffering under the latest Time/Warner Cable TV failure, I thought I would share the new excuse I just heard over the phone from one of their Service Center staffers, Natasha:</p>

<p>"It's all because of Global Warming!"</p>

<p>Given the magnitude of the problem, Natasha was unable to tell me when cable service would be restored.  I am calling the United Nations next for their estimate of when the problem will be rectified.</p>

<p>ps: If you want to get credit on your Time/Warner bill for days without service, you must call in and tell them, as Natasha instructed me, "The minute your service comes back on!"  --  Even if it's at 3:00 am.</p>

                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1422">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Special Feature: Locally Grown 2</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><br /><br /><center><script type="text/javascript" src="http://blip.tv/scripts/pokkariPlayer.js?ver=2007082501"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="http://blip.tv/syndication/write_player?skin=js&posts_id=358071&source=3&autoplay=true&file_type=flv&player_width=&player_height="></script><div id="blip_movie_content_358071"><a rel="enclosure" href="http://blip.tv/file/get/Eaustin-LocallyGrown2PerlaBatalla839.mov" onclick="play_blip_movie_358071(); return false;"><img title="Click to play" alt="Video thumbnail. <p>About this time last year, Jessie and i were grumbling all the way to Vegas.  We were on our way to celebrate the combined birthdays of some dear friends with some college-style shenanigans, drinking, costumed theme nights, and general foolishness in a neon-lit adult playground in the desert, but we were ALSO missing Jack Johnson playing literally down the street from our home at Locally Grown 1.  So this year, with the bill of Perla Batalla and Brett Dennen to lure us, we had our <a href="http://brownpapertickets.com/">brown paper tickets</a> nice and early.  Vegas can wait (and it helps to have a newborn).</p>

<p>We arrived just in time to hear MC Claud Mann welcoming everyone, and Battle-of-the-Bands fourth place winners The Imaginative Clams took the stage as we found a good spot to sit in the elite (as designated by the colored bracelets and plastic chains) "Front Lawn" section.  i gazed sadly backward at the row of faces that made up the front of the "Back Lawn" section with the <a href="http://www.fivemanelectricalband.ca/signslyrics.html">Five Man Electrical Band's "Signs"</a> playing in my head over whatever Avant Garage or The Philosophy were sharing from the stage.  And then it happened: Emy Reynolds began to play.<br />
</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">August 22, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001410"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1410">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Food For Thought Ojai's Locally Grown Concert Goes Green!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Ojai Post readers, there's a whole lot more going on here than the Zaca fire!  We've got a big event this weekend, the <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/06/food_for_thought_brings_locall.shtml">Locally Grown Concert</a>, and it is being touted as a green event.</p>

<p>"Ojai's Libbey Bowl is going substantially greener for Food For Thought's benefit concert featuring Perla Batalla and Brett Dennen," announced event coordinator, Marty Fujita. </p>

<p>The event, Locally Grown 2, which features not only Batalla and Dennen, but the winners of the August 4th Ojai -Ventura youth <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/08/food_for_thought_announces_bat.shtml">Battle of the Bands </a>competition, will benefit Food for Thought's farm-to-school program which educates children about healthy food choices and the importance of good environmental stewardship. Food For Thought's programs are in six of the seven schools of the Ojai Unified School District. The program also works with OUSD Food Service to introduce as much fresh, locally grown, seasonal produce into school meals as possible. </p>

<p>"We want this event not only to raise money for our program, but to be a model for how we can do large events, and keep our carbon footprint as small as possible. We may not be 100% green for this event, but we will be reaching for that standard," added Fujita.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/08/food_for_thought_ojais_locally.shtml">Continue reading "Food For Thought Ojai's Locally Grown Concert Goes Green!" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

<div><embed src="http://widget-4e.slide.com/widgets/slideticker.swf" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" quality="high" scale="noscale" salign="l" wmode="transparent" flashvars="cy=tp&il=1&channel=504403158269912398&site=widget-4e.slide.com" style="width:426px;height:320px" name="flashticker" align="middle"/><div style="width:426px;text-align:left;"><a href="http://www.slide.com/pivot?cy=tp&ad=1&id=504403158269912398&map=1" target="_blank"><img src="http://widget-4e.slide.com/p1/504403158269912398/tp_t016_v000_a001_f00/images/xslide1.gif" border="0" ismap="ismap" /></a> <a href="http://www.slide.com/pivot?cy=tp&ad=1&id=504403158269912398&map=2" target="_blank"><img src="http://widget-4e.slide.com/p2/504403158269912398/tp_t016_v000_a001_f00/images/xslide2.gif" border="0" ismap="ismap" /></a></div></div>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">A Weekend for Peace</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>Culture is defined by the images and symbols we use, our rituals and ceremonies, our histories and legends, and our heroes.  The weekend of September 21-23 is a major opportunity to celebrate Peace in a public and audio/visual way that directly builds a culture of peace...it is a time to be the change we wish to see.  Please consider how you can help locally.</em></p>

<p>We have some major opportunities for building a local culture of Peace coming up, and the main purpose of this post is to solicit volunteers for a variety of roles within that effort.  September 21st is <a href="http://www.internationaldayofpeace.org">International Peace Day</a>, and the Peace Alliance â the folks behind the <a href="http://www.thepeacealliance.org/">campaign for a federal Department of Peace</a> â will be coming to Ojai on that weekend to perform their play âThe Gift of Peaceâ at our own Libbey Bowl.  There will also be an Interfaith peace-focused schedule of ceremony, prayer, and music on Sunday the 23rd.  The collective Retreats of Ojai are on board with this in a big way and are organizing events during the entire Peace Weekend, and the Ojai Peace Coalition is going to be a part of it!</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">August 11, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001368"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1368">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">"Bodies Unbound" tonight at Ojai School of Massage</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Local writer and massage therapist <strong>Cynthia Waring Matthews</strong> tells her triumphant story. Based on her book, <em>Bodies Unbound</em>, tonight's performance features Cynthia in a one-woman theatre piece directed by <strong>Jill Andre. </strong></p>

<p><strong>Ojai School of Massage</strong><br />
619 W. El Roblar in Meiners Oaks<br />
8 pm - Tickets $15 at the door</p>

<p><strong>Cynthia Waring Matthews</strong> first escaped the sorrow of her early days by retreating to a convent as a young woman. Emerging after a time to re-enter the world at large, she was looking for an occupation and found herself absorbed into the world of bodywork, where she became a licensed massage therapist and massaged over 20,000 people in 30 years, from the anonymous to the dazzlingly famous, from infants to the elderly, from those seeking healing to those seeking a bodily indulgence. In her practice, she made a unique discovery: That through her fingers, she was able to read bodies and into the histories of the people beneath her hands. She could unlock the experiences and traumas stored in their bodies through cellular memories. </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/08/bodies_unbound_tonight_at_ojai.shtml">Continue reading ""Bodies Unbound" tonight at Ojai School of Massage" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Leslie Davis at 11:12 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/08/bodies_unbound_tonight_at_ojai.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/08/bodies_unbound_tonight_at_ojai.shtml#comments">Comments (4)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../leslie.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">July 30, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001338"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1338">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">"Glenn Was Here"</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/glenn_was_here.jpg" width="400" height="141" align="center" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></p>

<p>Glenn Emanuel's remembrance ceremony was yesterday at the gazebo in Libbey Park.  When i arrived at a few minutes before 4pm, there were but a handful of people gathered, most of whom were busily setting up easels of pictures and arranging chairs and sound equipment.  within minutes, the gathering swelled to a strong crowd that read like a who's-who of the Ojai Valley...i saw Sid and Sheila Cohn, the Al-Awars, Jim Calire, John Azevedo, Noel Douglas, Peggy La Cerra, and dozens of other very familiar faces that i personally dont even have names for.</p>

<p>we opened with music and prayer, and <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/07/in_remembrance_of_glenn_emmanu.shtml">elegant and heartfelt stories and reflections</a> were shared by friends and family.  as seems to be so often the case with those who leave us, these served to describe a person whom it feels beautiful to remember, but - as my wife observed as we solemnly left - whom we wish we'd known better while he was here.  it's clear that Glenn loved us all, and that we all loved him no matter how large or small our piece of his experience.</p>

<p>i believe that Cheri Mason-Emanuel's son said it best when he introspected that Glenn never seemed sad...always happy.  and so it hardly feels appropriate to be sad that he's gone; we can only be happy that he was here.  </p>

<p>"<em>Glenn was here</em>", etched with care into the picnic tables of our minds and hearts.  Ojai - and the world - are better for it.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 08:27 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/07/glenn_was_here.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/07/glenn_was_here.shtml#comments">Comments (10)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../evan.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                     </div>

                              <p>This post is all over the place, but it's been a typical week in Ojai where I run into all sorts of interesting people and great food.  I found the perfect sandwich, enjoyed a great evening of side-splitting laughter and met an inspiring and courageous woman - all right here in our little valley.</p>

<p><strong>Dishing Ojai: Oak Tree CafÃ© and Bakery:</strong><br />
I have finally found the perfect sandwich in Ojai at the Oak Tree CafÃ© and Bakery at the corner of Fox and Ojai Avenue.  I had the broiled open-faced tomato and mozzarella sandwich with olive tapenade spread and Bill had the albacore tuna salad sandwich with pesto spread (he threatened to order it "Mikeâs Way," but I stopped him).  Both were accompanied by a terrific salad tossed with shredded carrots, parmesan, tomatoes, their homemade croutons (which they sell by the bag) and choice of honey lemon or balsamic vinaigrette.  We sat outside under a shady pepper tree sipping sun-brewed iced tea and devoured every bite.  Oak Tree started as a small bakery and coffee stop down on Hwy. 33 in a converted ATM drive-thru selling the most amazing pastries.  They still have the pastries, but youâve got to get there early to enjoy them.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/07/dishing_ojai_feast_and_champag.shtml">More <em>Dishing Ojai </em>starts here.</a></p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">July 21, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001323"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1323">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">The Household Gods Rock the Playhouse for Glenn</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Jessie and i walked down to the Ojai Playhouse last night (so grateful we live close enough to do that!), arriving a few minutes after 5:30 to deposit our $40 - two 20's marked with PEACE, LOVE, & HEALTH - into the full fishbowl of medical fund collections for Glenn Emmanuel.  Music was already floating out of the propped-open auditorium doors, where <a href="http://www.householdgods.com">The Household Gods</a> had already begun their benefit set with a beautifully-lyric'd song that i missed the  title of.</p>

<p>There were maybe 50 people in the theater - sitting in small groups or alone - of all ages, and all seemed to be enjoying the music by nodding, clapping, or singing along with the Gods' master-full set, punctuated by instrument-switching and playful banter between songs.  If you've never heard the Gods (this was my second time), you're missing an exceptional piece of cultural Ojai and uniquely arranged covers of songs you know and love, as well as exposure to new favorites you didn't know you had.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/07/the_household_gods_rock_the_pl.shtml">Continue reading "The Household Gods Rock the Playhouse for Glenn" &raquo;</a>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Harry Potter and the Education Revolution</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">

                              <p>i gladly accepted the generous <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/06/magick_summer_in_mother_moon.shtml">invitation of Millennium and Megumi</a> to be with them at the Ojai Playhouseâs first screening of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Order_of_the_Phoenix_%28film%29">Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix</a>, the fifth in the seven part super-series.  we got there early enough to enjoy the antics and energy of the thicket of teenagers and preteens in front of us as the theater filled quickly behind us.  after only one preview (for the fresh-, funny-, and clever-looking âFred Clausâ), our adventure began.<br />
 <br />
iâm not going to review the film in great detail.  iâm not going to summarize the story, or play the cynical judge (too much). but i do have some insights about the appeal:<br />
i believe that it lies in the globality of it.  much like a national protest or vigil, or a global moment of silence or large-scale tragedy or the Olympics, thereâs something powerful and attractive about sharing an experience â any experience â with millions of other people all over our planet.  not only were we all and each immersed in the energy of a full theater where we have the comfortable space to laugh, cry, sigh, and scream as one, but there are people all over the globe doing the same thing.  i think we like that, even if we donât all take the time to specifically think about it.</p>

                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1235">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Farmer John Brings the Real Dirt to the Ojai Playhouse</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">

<p>No, itâs not about the sausage company.</p>

<p><em>The Real Dirt on Farmer John</em> is a movie about Illinois farmer John Petersen and his decades-long struggle to wrest right livelihood from his familyâs farm. Winner of over 30 festival awards, this film has it all â life, death, sex, terrorism, art, failure, success. Helped along by the fact that his mom started taking 16 mm movies of the family when John was a child, and by the fact that John is an artist as well as a bred-in-the-bones farmer, this movie reaches far beyond any normal expectations of a documentary about a mid-western farmer.</p>

<p>Presented by Food for Thought Ojai, the Ojai Film Society, and Slow Food Ojai/Ventura. <em>The Real Dirt on Farmer John </em>will show Saturday and Sunday, June 30-July 1, at 4:30 pm at the Ojai Playhouse in downtown Ojai. Tickets are $8 for adults, and $5 for seniors and students at the door.</p>

<p>Farmer John Petersen will be at BOTH screenings for Q &amp; A.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">June 10, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001227"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1227">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Glastonbury Music Festival Goes Green</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Let's take the lead of the Brits and create Ojai music & art festivals examples of environmentally conscious events as well. <br />
<strong><br />
Glastonbury Music Festival - June 22-24, 2007</strong></p>

<p>This years Glastonbury festival-goers will be asked to make a difference to climate change by reducing their carbon footprint. As well as eating organic food, washing in carbon neutral showers, using eco-friendly toilets and being supplied with recycled toilet paper, revellers will be invited to join the I Count campaign. It details 16 steps to reduce their environmental impact, and aims to sign up 100,000 people in three days. </p>

<p>The full line-up of musicians to perform at the <a href="http://www.glastonburyfestivals.co.uk"><strong>Glastonbury festival</strong></a> later this month has been announced.</p>

<p>The Who, The Killers and Arctic Monkeys will be headlining on the Pyramid Stage during the three-day event.Among the more than 200 acts listed are Rufus Wainwright, Lily Allen, Amy Winehouse, The Gossip, Paul Weller, Chemical Brothers and Shirley Bassey.The festival, which starts on 22 June, will be the largest yet, with an extended capacity of 177,500.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">June 07, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001214"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1214">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">40th Anniversary of Sgt. Peppers</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/sgtpeppergroupouttake2.jpg" width="480" height="283" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></p>

<p>June 1 was the 40th anniversary of Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (1967).</p>

<p>When I first heard Sgt.Pepper's by the Beatles it was one of those albums that jump started my inspiration and interest in music. The orchestral arrangements, sound scapes and phenomenal melodies (not to mention the cool outfits of the Fab four) kept me transfixed. I must have listened to it at least 2-3 times a day for months. Few things in life have this kind of impact on us. This was one for me.</p>

<p><strong>What event or... captivated and inspired you as a child?</strong></p>

<p><strong>Here's great article about the making of :</strong></p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.riprense.com/sgtpepper.htm">http://www.riprense.com/sgtpepper.htm</a></strong></p>

<p>It begins:   Many critics, I think, have forgotten that âPepperâ was a kind of pinnacle of genre, a new sort of music that had never exactly existed before. You no more dismiss its importance and achievement than you dismiss Beethovenâs Ninth Symphony because itâs 19th century orchestral music. Continuing that analogy, you donât evaluate the Ninth Symphony as a collection of movements that have no particular relationship to one another, and you do not evaluate âSgt. Pepperâ as a bunch of songs that happened to appear together on a vinyl disc. This album is a piece. Though not conceived as a whole, it was executed as one---the product of a single gigantic and intense series of recording sessions. It also bears remembering that there were no hits from âPepper,â no singles. The whole damn thing was a hit, and the biggest of its time, if not all time. In the summer of 1967, in many cities, you could not walk the length of a block without leaving earshot of this record. Humanityâs collective jaw was agape, its ears full of iridescent, irresistable sounds of a kind it had never heard before. </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Raymond Powers at 09:41 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/06/40th_anniversary_of_sgt_pepper.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/06/40th_anniversary_of_sgt_pepper.shtml#comments">Comments (3)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../raymond.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                     </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">May 22, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001194"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1194">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Music to Heal the Lungs By</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>i'd venture to guess that not many people know the names or faces of any of the projectionists at any of the corporate movie theaters in this country, even the "local" (read: geographically close) ones like Century.  but here in Ojai, our projectionist's name is Glenn Emanuel, and he's got the most gorgeous eyes and warm, ready smile.  he's a tall lanky fellow with a curly mop of hair and broad, expressive hands.  <em><strong>he's also got lung cancer.</strong></em></p>

<p>he told me this himself, when i saw him recently at Rainbow Bridge.  it was the first thing he said, and he did it with a slight smile on his face.  not that it isnt serious, but i strongly suspect that Glenn's got a specific and philosophical constitution that isnt very friendly to depression or sympathy-gathering.  i'm told by his partner Cheri Mason that Glen has chosen to forego the traditional toxic therapies for cancer, and is instead focusing on "nutrition, yoga, magnets, and herbs", and in honorable form is treating his cancer in the same way he treats others and the world: peacefullly, with life-affirming practices and natural cures.</p>

<p><strong><em>come meet the man and enjoy some great music at a donation-driven benefit for him this Friday evening May 25th at the Ojai Playhouse at 10pm, featuring Jim Calire and friends, Brad Bueley, Julie Christensen, and more.</em></strong>  interested musicians are encouraged to <a href="mailto:cheriamor@sbcglobal.net">contact Cheri</a>.  there is also an account set up in Glenn's name at Ojai Community Bank.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by evan austin at 06:33 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/05/music_to_heal_the_lungs_by.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/05/music_to_heal_the_lungs_by.shtml#comments">Comments (7)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../evan.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">May 19, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001187"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1187">
                        <h3 class="entry-header"><u><strong>Stop the Trucks: THERE IS NO DEAL!!!</strong></u></h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>                                                            </p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/%21cid_part1.3C9D21B2.2E77454F%40ojai%5B1%5D" width="100" height="75" align="center" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " />  <img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/%21cid_part1.3C58B191.1A9D9432%40ojai%5B1%5D" width="181" height="162" align="center" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></p>

<p><strong>"Paper Tiger, Toothless Dragon"</strong><br />
 <br />
<strong>Contrary to recent press stories, there is NO deal in place between Santa Barbara and Ventura Counties regarding the ban of gravel truck traffic on Route 33 from the proposed Diamond Rock Mine in the Cuyama Valley and Ojai.</strong></p>

<p>This alleged deal is nothing more than an attempt to undercut our opposition.  What they seek to do is an example of the classic political maneuvers of the  âThree Dâs:â  âDelay,â âDistractâ and/or âDeny.â  Do not be misled!</p>

<p>They seek to pull attention away from their latest (and substandard) EIR of May 2007 which we will not even dignify by calling it a âFinal EIR.â  There are logical holes in this EIR that a blind man could drive a fleet of gravel trucks through at night.  </p>

<p>But more dangerously, the CUP that they dangle in front of us contains no verification of  truck traffic.  It is a âPaper Tiger, a Toothless Dragon.â</p>

<p>President Franklin Delano Roosevelt once said, âDo not pass any laws you can not enforce because it only breeds disrespect for the law.â</p>

<p>Allowing self-monitoring of truck loads and drivers has already proven to be a disaster in Ventura County where a total failure of our own Planning Department to create CUPâs in 2001 and 2003 that have any verification or  enforcement  has left us with the 24/7 nightmare we now experience.   </p>

<p>Do not be misled.  There is no deal.  The only way we will win this war is with your total support and dedication.</p>

<p>Attend the hearing in Santa Maria!!!</p>

<p>Wednesday, May 30th at 9:00am in the "Board of Supervisors Hearing Room", <br />
511 E.Lakeside Parkway, Santa Maria, CA 93455.<br />
 <br />
The Diamond Rock final EIR is now available online at: <br />
 <a href="http://www.sbcountyplanning.org/projects/03CUP-00037/index.cfm">http://www.sbcountyplanning.org/projects/03CUP-00037/index.cfm</a><br />
 <br />
You can access this staff report at:  <br />
<a href="http://www.sbcountyplanning.org/boards/pc/cpc_documents.cfm?DocID=1967">http://www.sbcountyplanning.org/boards/pc/cpc_documents.cfm?DocID=1967</a><br />
 <br />
To Donate Online go to: <a href="http://www.ojaichamber.org/pages/coc/stop.asp">http://www.ojaichamber.org/pages/coc/stop.asp<br />
</a><br />
Or Use our pledge form below:</p>

<p> </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/05/stop_the_trucks_there_is_no_de.shtml">Continue reading "<u><strong>Stop the Trucks: THERE IS NO DEAL!!!</strong></u>" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">May 06, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001158"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1158">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Becoming a Fan</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/steve_nash_passing.jpg" width="300" height="200" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="2" alt="Steve_Nash_Passing " />After almost 10 years of marriage, Eric and I hooked up the Television. I have been able to avoid caring about Sports for a long time now, but it's <a href="http://www.nba.com/playoffs2007/index.html"target="_blank">NBA Playoff Season</a>, and the games are Live in my living room. And when something comes this close, you have almost no choice but to allow a relationship to develop. The trick is to start to learn the details. Understanding the strengths of the individual players' games, knowing the strategies and preferences of the different coaches, and getting the scoop on the team's management turns Basketball into a dramatic and entertaining piece of theatre.</p>

<p>Yet I am noticing that it is much easier to be interested and engaged when you have a favorite player, coach or team. Otherwise there is no emotional juice to draw you towards it. Trying to stay an intellectual observer is too boring and does not imprint the experience in the mind. But as soon as you allow yourself preferences, the experience becomes personal and relevant and you literally See the Game differently.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/05/becoming_a_fan.shtml">Continue reading "Becoming a Fan" &raquo;</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">April 25, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001129"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1129">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Language sliced open</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>I attended an inspiring poetry reading tonight in Ventura at the Artists' Union Gallery by our own, <a href="http://www.robertpeake.com">Robert Peake. </a></p>

<p>Robert has a calm, focused and direct stage presence that captivated the standing room only crowd. I was thrilled to see so many people come out for poetry on a Tuesday night! And thrilled to be out on a Tuesday night since I'm usually at home with my family.</p>

<p>Robert read a bunch of poems ranging from a euology to poet, Stanford Lyne, to poems about the loss of his young son, to childhood memories growing up in the border town of El Centro, California, to a couple of his own translations of Neruda and Machado (brilliant!). To top it off he ended the night with some hilarious poems about a carrot and a turnip and their vegetable cohorts. Hope to see more of that series in readings to come.</p>

<p>Robert, maybe you could post a poem or two ?</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Leslie Davis at 12:23 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/04/language_sliced_open.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">April 24, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001127"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1127">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">40 Years Ago in the Haight-Ashbury</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Turn On. Tune In. Drop Out!<br />
I got a little jolt last night as I sat in Upavistha Konasana (Seated Wide Angle Pose) watching the PBS documentary on Hippies and the Summer of Love. It dawned on me that it was 40 years ago (1967)  that I took the Greyhound bus from Ventura to San Francisco and rented a room on the third story of a house on the Haight. For the first time in my life I was free to draw around the clock with Bob Dylan and Simon and Garfunkle in the background. I could sit for hours on the window ledge, in my painted jeans, watching the unfolding hippy invasion below. From my third story perch I could spot Janis Joplin in the crowd and hear Country Joe and the Fish playing nearby. Imagine growing up in Ojai and suddenly finding yourself transported  amongst 20,000 people dancing in Golden Gate Park! The documentary showed  the Human Be-In, a Gathering of the Tribes, and all the great counterculture gurus.  I remembered how I made money selling my art, babysitting the four poor children who lived in the basement below, and peddling the Berkeley Barb. You could buy a ten pound bag of brown-rice for $1 and get clothes at the Free Store. I don't remember ever eating the Free Food. When I ran out of rice I fasted to protest the Vietnam War. My AWOL boyfriend was picked up by the military police in the dead of night and locked up in the Presidio.  Did anyone else see the PBS special last night? Did you see yourself?  As I stretched forward in Upavisthakonasana I had this great cosmic insight that we're all still trying to turn on, tune in and drop out... Is that what growing older is all about?</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 07:43 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/04/40_years_ago_in_the_haightashb.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/04/40_years_ago_in_the_haightashb.shtml#comments">Comments (26)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../suza.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                                          

                     <h2 class="date-header">April 14, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001099"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1099">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Where Subway Is And Isn't...</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Hope you are enjoying your gloomy Saturday in Ojai... There is a nice article in Canadian publication The Star Phoenix on the <a href="http://www.canada.com/saskatoonstarphoenix/news/weekend_extra/story.html?id=39c6263f-5db9-4958-9061-df82b9c104c5">Ojai Valley Inn & Spa</a>.  Money quote:</p>

<blockquote>With a 360-degree view of the dramatic mountain range, the 89-hectare Spanish colonial- style resort is nestled snugly within the valley.  The air is noticeably fresh -- if not sweet -- compared to L.A. several hundred metres below.

<p>With complimentary valet service, we leave our car behind and forget it exists until check-out two days later. The attention to detail is beyond expectation -- especially after having just disembarked an Air Canada flight where the menu selection is no longer chicken or beef, but water or orange juice, with the option to buy an overpriced, nearly naked, six-inch Subway sub.</blockquote></p>

<p>Get it?  <strong>Ojai is a place that people come to <em>from around the world</em> to get away from Subway.</strong>  By preventing the urgent moratorium and allowing the Subway franchisee to file for the necessary permits, Joe DeVito has single-handedly torpedoed the very perception of what Ojai is.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Tyler Suchman at 03:28 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/04/where_subway_is_and_isnt.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/04/where_subway_is_and_isnt.shtml#comments">Comments (19)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../tyler.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 28, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001058"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1058">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Innovation 101 and the Conquest of Fire</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>In business as in life, if you are not innovating, re-inventing or improving what you do, your competitors are.</p>

<p>Although most people are terrified of change, there is no greater recipe for failure than inertia, doing things as they have always been done.  </p>

<p>Ellison S. Onizuka, one of our astronauts whose death in the 1987 crash of the  space shuttle Challenger illustrated the danger of risk taking, said it best in a speech he gave to students few years earlier.</p>

<p>âThe people who make this world run, whose lives can be termed successful, whose names will go down in history books, are not the cynics, the critics, or the armchair quarterbacks.  They are the adventurers, the explorers, and the doers of this world.  When they see a wrong or a problem, they do something about it...  Rather than leaning back and criticizing how things are, they work to make things the way they should be.  They are the aggressive, the self-starters, the innovative, and the imaginative of this worldâ¦.  â   <br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/03/innovation_101_and_the_conques.shtml">Continue reading "Innovation 101 and the Conquest of Fire" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Howard Smith at 05:55 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/03/innovation_101_and_the_conques.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/03/innovation_101_and_the_conques.shtml#comments">Comments (0)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../howard.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 25, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001049"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1049">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Music</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>I recently had the pleasure of meeting Fred Schmitt, a prolific singer/songwriter and a musical genius, who lives right here in our little valley.  He's the real deal.  He's been writing music for 35 years and has traveled some million miles over 46 states playing to anyone who would listen.  He has written over 200 songs and finds it hard to keep the muse at bay.  And he doesn't have a recording contract.  Incredible.</p>

<p>I chatted him up over coffee this afternoon at Stir Crazy with my friend Matt and turned the mics on to capture a couple of his songs, too.  The interview and the music are on Radio Ojai.  <a href="http://radioojai.com/">Take a listen</a> - I think you'll feel like I do...like I've just gotten a sneak peak of someone on the verge of great success.  Any second now, he'll be in Nashville.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/03/ojai_music.shtml">Continue reading "Ojai Music" &raquo;</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 23, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001047"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1047">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">The Ojai Post Poetry Center</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><strong>this moment</strong><br />
  <br />
a bright sliver of the moon hangs over<br />
the dark shadowy mountains of the <br />
valley of the moon<br />
i stand stone still <br />
watching the first glimmers of dawn<br />
the quarter moon so bright it <br />
almost looks full<br />
the valley below so silent<br />
like the beginning of time<br />
no busy minds...no cars...<br />
only the soft soft hooting of the owl</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Suza Francina at 11:14 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/03/the_ojai_post_poetry_center.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 08, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001023"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1023">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Poetry Festival Tickets On Sale Now</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/poetry_matters_in_ventura_and.shtml"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/shi.gif" width="72" height="72" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="Poetry Matters! " style="float: right; border: 0px; padding-left: 10px; padding-right: 10px; padding-bottom: 10px;" border="0" /></a><a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/order.html">The Ojai Poetry Festival is now selling tickets</a> on their website for the <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/">2007 festival</a> on May 18-19 in Libbey Bowl. This season brings another four poets of international repute - <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/poets/Snyder.html">Gary Snyder</a>, <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/poets/Alexie.html">Sherman Alexie</a>, <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/poets/Alcosser.html">Sandra Alcosser</a> and <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/poets/Mel%E9ndez.html">Mar&iacute;a Mel&eacute;ndez</a> - to Ojai and again includes a <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/teen.html">Teen Poetry Contest</a>, regional poets reading and open mic events. </p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/order.html">all-event pass</a> is your best option to make sure not to miss a minute of what promises to be the best season yet. Students with valid ID also qualify for <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/order.html">half-price admission</a> to all events. So get your tickets early and be sure to spread the word. </p>

<p>For those of you interested in helping out, the next volunteer's meeting will be held on Thursday, April 5th at 7PM in the Ojai Library.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 27, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a001007"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-1007">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Happy Birthday, Ojai Post!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Exactly one year ago today, I <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/02/welcome_to_the_ojai_post.shtml">posted</a> this <strike>warning</strike> welcome:</p>

<blockquote>The Ojai Post is a community blog, featuring Ojai residents from all walks of life writing about the unique Ojai experience. Ojai is a special place, not just for its geography, flora and fauna, small-town architecture and rich native American history - its also because of the people - talented, creative souls who tend to walk to the beat of their own drummer and carve their own path through life. Check in for daily musings, rants, Ojai news and greater goings-on from the place some call Shangri-La.</blockquote>

<p>We've certainly had our share of musings, rants, news and greater goings-on - 425 posts and counting.  And we're just getting started.  My deep gratitude to twenty-two authors who have dipped in a toe or taken the plunge, and to our ever-increasing audience (over 1,500 visitors and 5,000 page views yesterday).   The Ojai Post is about community, one I'm proud to be a part of.   Hope you're enjoying the ride as much as I am.</p>

                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Tyler Suchman at 12:00 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/02/happy_birthday_ojai_post.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 08, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a000973"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-973">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Stop the Trucks; Update of February 9th</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The response period for the EIR is now closed.  </p>

<p>I want to personally thank the hundreds of concerned citizens of the region who took the time to write letters to Gary Kaiser.  They have already had an impact!</p>

<p>According to a news story in the Pacific Coast Business Times, a final draft of the EIR will be completed by the end of the month.  Your letters will be included according to a conversation I've had with Gary Kaiser.  The Santa Barbara County Planning Comission will review and decide on the merits of the EIR at their April Meeting.  If approved there are a number of other, smaller regulatory issues that must be dealt with.  If everything passes approval, the whole issue is expected to go to the Santa Barbara County Supervisors in late summer or the fall.</p>

<p>Our "Stop the Trucks" committee, which has so far been an infomal collection of concerned citizens, will be meeting at the end of February for an open "brainstorming" meeting. <br />
 <br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/02/stop_the_trucks_update_of_febr.shtml">Continue reading "Stop the Trucks; Update of February 9th" &raquo;</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 03, 2007</h2>
                     <a id="a000962"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-962">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">How I Spent Groundhog Day!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Gore%20and%20Guggenheim%20small6.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Gore%20and%20Guggenheim%20small6.shtml','popup','width=512,height=384,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0'); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Gore%20and%20Guggenheim%20small-thumb.jpg" width="100" height="75" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></a>No doubt it was a rhetorical question, but awhile back a reader asked if I would be giving an account of how I spent Groundhog Day.  Well, I didn't think there would be much worth mentioning except the fact that the little rodent would go back into his den and give us 6 more weeks of winter (although you wouldn't know it on a day like today).  But it was a little more exciting than that.  I had a face-to-face interview with Al Gore on the red carpet at his screening of <em>An Inconvenient Truth</em> at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival.  Playing reporter was very different than the role I played as <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/01/the_price_of_paradise_screens.shtml">filmmaker</a> earlier in the week, but thrilling given who was answering my question.  Tune in for more after I decipher my notes!  Meanwhile, read evan's previous post about the movie <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/06/an_inconvenient_truth.shtml">here</a>.<br />
<em>Photo of Al Gore and Davis Guggenheim 2/2/07 (click to enlarge)</em><br />
Also check-out a red carpet podcast with environmentalist, actor and former Ojai resident Noah Wyle on <a href="http://radioojai.com/">Radio Ojai</a>.</p>

                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Lisa Snider at 01:03 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2007/02/how_i_spent_groundhog_day.shtml">Permalink</a>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Better Than Chocolate! (Poetry)</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/poetry_matters_in_ventura_and.shtml"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/shi.gif" width="72" height="72" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="Poetry Matters! " style="float: right; border: 0px; padding-left: 10px; padding-right: 10px; padding-bottom: 10px;" border="0" /></a>This year's annual Erotic Poetry & Spoken Word reading at the <a href="http://www.venturaartistsunion.org/" target="_blank">Artist's Union Gallery</a> in Ventura will be held on Saturday, Feb. 10th at 7:00 pm. This reading celebrates the erotic in the broadest sense - works that evoke yearning, longing, and loss, as well as the more traditional praises of desire and tributes to the beloved - and commemorates the opening of the Artistsâ Union Gallery's annual erotic art exhibition.</p>

<p>âEroticism,â says event-host Friday, âis most easily found in food, poetry, art and sex; three of the four items mentioned will be provided for you at the benefit.â  The line-up includes <a href="http://web.mac.com/r.w.b/iWeb/Site/Playa%20Poets%20Home.html" target="_blank">Richard Beban</a>, author of <i>What the Heart Weighs</i>, Bay Area author Adrienne Marcus, poet/publisher <a href="http://www.solopress.org/Solo%20Press%20Web/Glenna%20Luschei.html" target="_blank">Glenna Luschei</a>, and many others.  âWe are so lucky to have such an incredible assemblage of talent under the same roof.  We expect to hear poems from ardent to zany, and everything in-between.  All that energy should make for an intense reading,â says co-organizer Phil Taggart.</p>

<p>âAccording to Hesiod, Eros instills all notions of beauty and anguish within our souls,â says co-organizer and award-winning poet, Marsha de la O.  âBoth beauty and anguish are principal considerations of poetry.  We wanted to give a distinguished group of Southern Californian poets the opportunity to explore the nuances of eroticism in an environment where visual artists and sculptors have used other media to explore the same concept.â</p>

<p>Admission is $10 at the door.  The event is a benefit with all proceeds going to the Artistsâ Union Gallery.  The Artistsâ Union Gallery is located at 330 South California Street in Ventura.</p>

<p>Poets reading include: Joyce LaMers, Jackson Wheeler, Tim Tipton, Roe Estep, Shelley Savren, Elijah Imlay, Ryan Gillenwater, Richard Beban, Howard Billou, Carol Davis, Carlye Archibeque, Ellen Reich, Florence Weinberger, Adrianne Marcus, Doris Vernon, Glenna Luschei, Perie Longo, Virginia Mariposa, Robert Peake, Teka Lark-Lo, Laura Diamond, Mary Kay Rummel, Lee Rossi, Tim Pompey, Cathryn Andreson, Larry Colker, Patricia Lynn Belkovitz, Bob Sterling, Marsha de la O, Friday and Phil Taggart.<br />
</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">January 21, 2007</h2>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">The Price of Paradise Screens in Santa Barbara</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://bp0.blogger.com/_HeFzMiFvgis/RbPoV2SEYUI/AAAAAAAAAB4/MboydKVrMV8/s1600-h/production+still+by+brooks+smothers.gif"><img id="BLOGGER_PHOTO_ID_5022613471494431042" style="FLOAT: left; MARGIN: 0px 10px 10px 0px; CURSOR: hand" alt="" src="http://bp0.blogger.com/_HeFzMiFvgis/RbPoV2SEYUI/AAAAAAAAAB4/MboydKVrMV8/s200/production+still+by+brooks+smothers.gif" border="0" /></a></p>

<p>There has been a lot of talk on these pages about affordable housing.  What does that mean to you?  Who should have it?  What should it look like?  Where should it be built?  The documentary, <em>The Price of Paradise</em>, does not seek to answer these questions, but rather engage a dialog.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">December 22, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000895"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-895">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Palestine Peace Not Apartheid</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/C_0743285026.jpg" width="168" height="250" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></p>

<p>When our family moved to the United States in 1974, we stopped in Israel and 
  Jordan to visit some of the holy places. I remember visiting the wailing wall, 
  calvary, and the location of Christ's tomb. Though I was only 7, it left an 
  impression on me. <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_nixon">Richard 
  Nixon</a> resigned a month after our arrival. I have vague memories of these 
  times but I can honestly say the first President I really remember is <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_carter">Jimmy 
  Carter</a>. Carter has been a hero of mine for many years because of his honesty, 
  integrity, and his work for peace. In particular, the <a href="http://www.cartercenter.org/">Carter 
  Center</a>, founded by Carter, has the goal for advancing human rights and alleviating 
  suffering. Recently I read his new book <em><a href="http://www.simonsays.com/content/book.cfm?tab=1&pid=522298">Palestine 
  Peace Not Apartheid</a></em> with great interest. I was curious to see what 
  this prominent Nobel Peace Prize winner had to say about the Middle East, especially 
  in using the word '<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apartheid">apartheid</a>' 
  in the title. </p>

                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/12/palestine_peace_not_apartheid.shtml">Continue reading "Palestine Peace Not Apartheid" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Kenley Neufeld at 10:23 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/12/palestine_peace_not_apartheid.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/12/palestine_peace_not_apartheid.shtml#comments">Comments (2)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../kenley.shtml">author bio</a>

With your help, support, and patronage, this year's festival promises to be the best one yet. <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/subscribe/newsletter.html">Sign up for the newsletter</a> to stay current with news leading up to the festival and to be notified when <a href="http://www.ojaipoetryfestival.org/tickets.html">tickets go on sale</a>.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">November 28, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000859"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-859">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojaiku</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>My most recent post about poetry in this area was met with a spontaneous flurry of poems in the comment section. As a result, and at Tyler's prompting, I thought it might be fun to invite readers of The Ojai Post to submit Haiku. To submit a poem or read others already submitted, simply click the comment link right underneath this article. If you already know what Haiku is all about, you can skip down there now to read and write some Haiku.</p>

<p>For those of you unfamiliar with the form, English Haiku is loosely based on the Japanese form from which it gets the name. In English Haiku, the only constraint is that each line have a certain number of syllables. It is actually quite easy: the first line must have five syllables, the second line seven, and the third line five again. That's it. Three lines, twelve syllables total.</p>

<p>Traditional Japanese Haiku usually sprung from deep observation of nature. Often the first two lines are meditative and descriptive, and the third and final line of a Haiku presents some element of surprise or revelation, or perhaps a new angle on the subject. This is not always the case, but works well to delight the reader and hopefully leave them with a lasting impression. Here is probably the most famous of all Haiku by a seventeenth century poet named <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matsuo_Basho">BashÅ</a>:</p>

<blockquote>The old pond<br />
frog jumps in -<br />
water's sound.</blockquote>

<p>(Note: because this was translated from Japanese, the English version does not conform to the 5, 7, and 5 syllables rule. But it gives you a flavor of traditional Haiku.)</p>

<p>If you are interested, you can read more about the Haiku form <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haiku">here</a>.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Robert Peake at 08:03 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/11/ojaiku.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/11/ojaiku.shtml#comments">Comments (10)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../robert.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                     </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">November 18, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000842"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-842">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Thomas Pynchon, illustrated; 'Gravity's Rainbow' in images</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>LA TIMES BOOK REVIEW by Emily Barton</p>

<p>Gravity's Rainbow Illustrated: One Picture for Every Page<br />
Zak Smith<br />
Tin House: 784 pp., $39.99</p>

<p><br />
<img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/801-pynchonadd.jpg" width="240" height="200" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></p>

<p>Thomas Pynchon's 1973 novel, "Gravity's Rainbow," is still so frenetic, paranoid, preternaturally sharp, abrupt in its changes of subject and tone and relentless in its probing of the sinister connections among sex, high-tech polymers and the Blitz that a person would have to be slightly off to think he understands it enough to illustrate it.</p>

<p>Yet Zak Smith, with uninhibited bravado and exactly the right kind of insanity, has done something remarkable in "Gravity's Rainbow Illustrated": created a series of images that approach the richness of their source. He draws a lurid and intoxicating netherworld, complete in its own right and, at the same time, an illuminating companion to the novel. Since all editions of "Gravity's Rainbow" seem to be printed from the same plates, each one of Smith's illustrations will correspond to one page of the foxed copy you've been trucking around since college. </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/11/thomas_pynchon_illustrated_gra_1.shtml">Continue reading "Thomas Pynchon, illustrated; 'Gravity's Rainbow' in images" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Join us for a Cuppa Joe at 3pm</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">

<p>We were mentioned in the <a href="http://www.vcreporter.com/article.php?id=3997&IssueNum=98" target"_blank">VC Reporter this week</a>, but let me add that Cuppa Joe was first proposed by Todd Miller and championed by evan austin and a number of our readers.  It's a great idea.  See you there, hope you can make it.</p>

<p><strong>[UPDATE: 6:47pm] </strong>Thanks to all fifteen individuals for coming on down to Stir Crazy and participating in the very first, but not last, Cuppa Joe.  It was great to see a bunch of familiar faces, meet a few new people and exchange some dialogue.  Consider this an open thread on the event and how you'd like to see it evolve.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">November 16, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000838"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-838">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Spoken Word Salon At Zoey's In Ventura</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/poetry_matters_in_ventura_and.shtml"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/shi.gif" width="72" height="72" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="Poetry Matters! " style="float: right; border: 0px; padding-left: 10px; padding-right: 10px; padding-bottom: 10px;" border="0" /></a>How many English composition classes serve espresso under atmospheric lighting? As far as I know, only one - and they meet the third Thursday of the month at Zoey's cafe on Main Street in Ventura. Sometimes student-centered open mics get a bad rap for laborious rough-draft poetry and undergraduate antics. Not this place. Tonight featured two top-notch local poets and a brief line up of quality open mic readers. </p>

<p><a href="http://academic.venturacollege.edu/galley/">Gwendolyn Alley</a> hosts the series and teaches the class, and thanks to her broad interests and teacherly charm, she gives the evening a casual, positive feel while promoting everything from slam to language poetry to narrative free verse. Literally, there's something for everyone here. If you want to hear some local talent (emphasis on the talent) or read some of your own work as well, be sure to check out Zoey's on the third Thursday of every month starting at 7:30 PM.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Robert Peake at 10:45 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/11/spoken_word_salon_at_zoeys_in.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/11/spoken_word_salon_at_zoeys_in.shtml#comments">Comments (1)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../robert.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">November 12, 2006</h2>

                     <div class="entry" id="entry-832">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Ojai Valley-wide Discussion (Open Thread)</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>330 people filed into Nordoff High's gym to participate in the first of three Discussions over the next year.  I'm off to dinner and a play at the art center, so I'll give some brief stats, and open up the online discussion...</p>

<p>On a scale of 1-9, the following nine issues were first identified by the gathering as the top issues, and then ranked accordingly...</p>

<p>more/better transit options: 5<br />
emergency preparedness plan: 7<br />
emergency room: 3<br />
valley-wide communication: 4<br />
valley plan for development: 8<br />
gangs & crime: 5<br />
green & sustainability: 7<br />
traffic: 8<br />
after-school and youth programs: 6</p>

<p>Shout out to evan austin, Kenley Neufeld, Sue Horgan, Rae Hanstad, Bret Bradigan, Steve Olsen, Glenn Emannuel, Dennis Leary, Pete LaFollette, Dave Lawrence and everyone else who took the time to come on down to participate.  Steve Bennett and his staff did a really great job preparing and running the discussion.</p>
