                     <h2 class="date-header">October 31, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000810"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-810">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Poetry Matters In Ventura And Santa Barbara County</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <div style="float: left; border: 0px; padding-left: 10px; padding-right: 10px; padding-bottom: 10px; width:130px;"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shi_%28poetry%29"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/shih.gif" width="130" height="126" border="0" alt="Shi, Chinese Character For Poem" onMouseOver="self.status = 'Shi, Chinese Character For Poem'; return true;" onMouseOut="self.status = ''; return true;" /></a><br /><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shi_%28poetry%29"><span style="font-size: 10px;">Shi, Chinese Character For Poem</span></a></div>Hello Ojai. A brief introduction: you probably haven't seen me around too much, though I've lived here for a couple of years. I tend to keep to myself. That said, I love community and this one in particular. And I love poetry. So please join me as I seek to uncover goings on in this area related to literature, writing, and the arts. So far the process has been a lot like flipping over stones after a rain and finding all sorts of interesting things wriggling underneath them.

<p>Here's one big stone: probably the best resource for poetry events in this area, and <a href="javascript:if(window.external) {window.external.AddFavorite('http://www.poetix.net/ventura.htm','Poetix.Net');}else{window.location = 'http://www.poetix.net/ventura.htm';}" onClick="if(window.external) {window.external.AddFavorite('http://www.poetix.net/ventura.htm','Poetix.Net');}else{window.location = 'http://www.poetix.net/ventura.htm';}">one I recommend you bookmark right now</a> is <a href="http://www.poetix.net/ventura.htm">Poetix.Net</a>. Phil Taggart does an excellent job of maintaining a fairly comprehensive listing of poetry goings on for Ventura and Santa Barbara counties.</p>

<p>In the realm of poetry superstars, Lawrence Ferlenghetti (who was featured at last year's <a href="http://www.ovlff.com/poetryfestival/poetryfestival.htm">Ojai Poetry Festival</a>) will be <a href="http://www.sbpoetry.net/events.html">reading in Santa Barbara</a> this coming Thursday. And Pulitzer Prize winning poet Mary Oliver is coming to our area in January. Lots more poetic goodness on the horizon. Join me as I uncover more offerings, one stone at a time.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Robert Peake at 09:02 AM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/poetry_matters_in_ventura_and.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/poetry_matters_in_ventura_and.shtml#comments">Comments (3)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../robert.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>

                        <h3 class="entry-header">Introduction / greetings</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><br><blockquote><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/jock.shtml">Jock Doubleday</a> was suspended as an author in October 2008.  Despite his <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2008/10/jock-doubleday-censorship.shtml">claims of censorship</a>, none of his posts have been removed. </blockquote> </p>

<p><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Jock-2004-%28web%29.jpg" width="320" height="482" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt="Jock Doubleday" /></p>

<p>Greetings!</p>

<p>As Shakespeare never said:</p>

<blockquote>Now is the summer of our discontent made glorious autumn . . .</blockquote>

<p>And a glorious autumn it is.</p>

<p>I've lived in Ojai for several years, sometimes making sojourns to distant lands like Poland (to teach English), Panama (to take photos), and Gettysburg -- where I recently wrote a play called "Christmas on the Mason-Dixon Line."</p>

<p>I'm hoping to produce the play at one of the theaters in Ojai.</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">

                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Jock Doubleday at 07:47 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/introduction_greetings.shtml">Permalink</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">October 09, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000770"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-770">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Lighten Up Ojai!  The Ojai Film Festival</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/yellowdog7%20small.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/yellowdog7%20small.shtml','popup','width=444,height=290,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0'); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/yellowdog7%20small-thumb.jpg" width="100" height="65" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></a><br />
I knew that would get your attention!  I just thought I'd round things out and offer a bit of levity - I think we're ready.  All this politicking is getting me down, so I thought I would remind everyone to take advantage of the Ojai Film Festival, which opens this Thursday night.  A perfect opportunity to check-out, tune-in and suspend belief for awhile (that is unless you are taking in a documentary, so pace yourself).  I wrote an article about it, which is also now on newsstands in the <em>Ojai Visitors Guide</em>:</p>

<p><em>Photo from "The Cave of the Yellow Dog," courtesy of the Ojai Film Festival.</em></p>

<p>I will always say the best time to visit Ojai is during the autumnal equinox.  Whenever anyone quips that Californians donât have seasons, I simply retort, âSounds like you havenât been to Ojai in October.â  The liquid amber treesâ verdant leaves seem to turn to earth, rust and gold right before your eyes while an early morning light casts an umber glow across the valley that signals fallâs arrival.  Shadows lengthen and crisp sunny days yield bright blue skies that frame the Topa Topas in such a way that youâre sure you can reach out and grab Chief Peakâs nose.  And clear starry nights beckon you to a bench under a blanket in Libbey Bowl beneath 200-year-old oak trees to gaze up into a movie screen on the opening night of the Ojai Film Festival.  Itâs nothing short of magical.<br />
</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/lighten_up_ojai.shtml">Continue reading "Lighten Up Ojai!  The Ojai Film Festival" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Lisa Snider at 07:45 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/lighten_up_ojai.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/lighten_up_ojai.shtml#comments">Comments (4)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../lisa.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">October 04, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000761"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-761">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Study shows The Daily Show is as substantive as CBS Evening News</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>No, I'm not kidding.  </p>

<p>From a <a href="http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20061004-7908.html">study</a> done by an assistant professor at Indiana University:</p>

<p>"The Daily Show is much funnier than traditional newscasts, but a new study from Indiana University says it has the same amount of meat on its bones when it comes to coverage of the news. The brand of news coverage Jon Stewart and the rest of The Daily Show's staff brings to the airwaves is just as substantive as traditional news programs like World News Tonight and the CBS Evening News, according to the study conducted by IU assistant professor of telecommunications Julia R. Fox and a couple of graduate students."</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Heather McKenzie at 10:43 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/study_shows_the_daily_show_is.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/10/study_shows_the_daily_show_is.shtml#comments">Comments (2)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../heather.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">September 04, 2006</h2>

                     <div class="entry" id="entry-704">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Special Maritime Museum Exhibit by Painter Qi Pang</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>I want to call your attention to a special exhibition at the Ventura County Maritime Museum from September 1st thru October 2nd by the renowned Chinese artist, Qi Pang, who help us curate and mount our program on the Chinese Treasure Fleets of the 15th Century earlier this year.</p>

<p>Mr. Pang will showcase a collection of works that demonstrate a lyrical sense of form combined with historical detail that produce images of exotic and timeless beauty.  A well established painter from Heilongjiang, China, Mr. Pang has also served as an art designer and appraiser of ancient works of calligraphy and paintings for more than thirty years at the Jilin Museum.</p>

<p>There will be an Opening Reception at the Museum on Saturday, September 9 from 3-6 pm.  Qi Pang also created the mural that now graces China Alley in Ventura just across the street from the Mission.</p>

<p>I hope you will have an opportunity to attend.  His work his truly wonderful and should not be missed.  For more details see the attached invitation card.  Thank you.<br />

                     <h2 class="date-header">July 09, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000648"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-648">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Summer Reading</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p><em>Summer, it turns me upside down.<br />
Summer, summer, summer, itâs like a merry-go-round.</em></p>

<p><a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Sydney%20Mid%20Flight3.shtml" onclick="window.open('http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Sydney%20Mid%20Flight3.shtml','popup','width=406,height=283,scrollbars=no,resizable=no,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=no,left=0,top=0'); return false"><img src="http://www.ojaipost.com/images/Sydney%20Mid%20Flight-thumb.JPG" width="143" height="100" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" border="1" alt=" " /></a>Itâs Sunday, and as is typical on a Sunday in July, Iâm soaking in the cool green muck that clings to the corners and curves of my pool.  Hundred degree days invite the emerald monster to creep in despite due diligence with chemicals and brushing.  </p>

<p>I wade in, brush in hand, ready to tackle the task at hand.  I scour, scrub and scrape, coaxing the grime away until my shoulders begin to strain.  Now and then the handle slips and I grate my knuckles on the side of the pool.  The scab from last week was just healing when I manage to grind it off again.  I wince just as a breeze kicks up, blowing more oak leaves in.  I had just scooped a net-full off.  I grab the net again, scooping more leaves and a drowning yellow jacket, too, who had no doubt just buzzed in for a drink.  A spider hangs off the coping and refuses to get into the net.  I grab the brush again and whisk it away.  A water bug swims around my waist.  Heâs swift and cunning, but I finally catch him and hoist him onto the deck.  Sydney, my yellow lab, sniffs at the hopping pest then quickly moves on to other smells in the yard.  I feel something crawling on my back. </p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/07/summer_reading.shtml">Continue reading "Summer Reading" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Lisa Snider at 05:29 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/07/summer_reading.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/07/summer_reading.shtml#comments">Comments (1)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../lisa.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">June 26, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000629"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-629">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Censorship for Whose Own Good?</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>I ran over to Bartâs Books Saturday afternoon to see if I could find a Ray Bradbury book.  I figured if I was going to a book signing, I ought to have a book for him to sign.  Iâm ashamed to say that I skimmed <em>Fahrenheit 451</em> in high school and spent more time with the Cliffâs Notes than the book itself, though it was practically beat into me how important this book was.  So, happy to have any excuse to venture into Bartâs Books, I willingly got lost between the stacks, meeting the torn and dusty likes of Joyce, Bronte, James and low and behold, nestled amongst the Sci-Fi section, Bradbury.  There was only one copy of <em>F. 451 </em>and I snatched it up like it was the last pixie tangerine of the season at the Farmers Market.  I read the inside cover: âFahrenheit 451 â the temperature at which book paper catches fire, and burnsâ¦â  An early eighties reprint, itâs in relatively good shape, with yellowing pages and notes in the margins that tell me this book was loved.  And at $7.50, a bargain find.</p>

<p>I sat side-by-side with aspiring authors at the <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/06/santa_barbara_writers_conferen.shtml">Santa Barbara Writers Conference</a>, waiting for Ray Bradbury to take the stage.  I eye the crowd, which was absolutely what you would expect of wannabe writers.  Not particularly well-dressed or even necessarily well-groomed, but certainly well-prepared and exceedingly punctual: a graying, balding, fifty-something bespectacled man with not three hairs on his head proudly collected into a pony tail; a tall, brooding, dark, big-haired woman with a fuzzy leopard print hat.  Nearly everyone had a writing implement, be it pen and paper or an IMac.  Geeks galore.  And I was one of them.  At least I tried to be.  Oh, hell, I desperately <em>yearned</em> to be!</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/06/censorship_for_whose_own_good.shtml">Continue reading "Censorship for Whose Own Good?" &raquo;</a>
                              </p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Lisa Snider at 04:00 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/06/censorship_for_whose_own_good.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/06/censorship_for_whose_own_good.shtml#comments">Comments (5)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../lisa.shtml">author bio</a>

                     <h2 class="date-header">June 23, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000626"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-626">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Santa Barbara Writers Conference This Weekend</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The <a href="http://www.sbwc.org/index.php">Santa Barbara Writers Conference </a>starts tomorrow and runs through next Friday at the DoubleTree Resort.  At $795 plus meals and lodging, I think I will just take advantage of the individually ticketed events.  </p>

<p>Ray Bradbury, author of the <em>Martian Chronicles </em>and <em>Fahrenheit 451</em>, is opening the conference tomorrow evening for the 34th year in a row.   He has held this tradition since the conference first started in 1972.  They say that if you have never heard him speak, you must.  I'm grabbing a ticket at the door for just $15.00.</p>

<p>Read on for more details and other <a href="http://www.sbwc.org/about_speakers.php">featured authors</a>, such as John Grogan, Erica Jong, Nilo Cruz and T.C. Boyle...</p>
                                                            <p class="entry-more-link">
                                 <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/06/santa_barbara_writers_conferen.shtml">Continue reading "Santa Barbara Writers Conference This Weekend" &raquo;</a>

The band has been featured in Rolling Stone, CNN, The Los Angeles Times, The New York Times, and now The Ojai Post.  </p>

<p>Eric Gould, bassist and founding member, told me in a recent interview that he and the band are looking forward to coming to Ojai, a place he visited once just a couple of years ago but has never played.  âWe love playing places for the first time.â  Having been on the road so much, being able to play just an hour and a half from Los Angeles feels like they are at home, particularly since they can just hop in a car and not have to drag out the tour bus.</p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 17, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000451"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-451">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">saw Ashes and Snow... loved it</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>Saint Patrick - w00t! <br />
I'm happy to announce that I've been dating a very lovely blues singer for one year now. Her name is April Hendrix. You can hear her sing at <a href="http://www.movinowinebar.com">Movino's</a> in the Ojai Arcade on Friday evening, March 31st from 8:30 till the wee hours. So anyway, to celebrate our anniversary, we cruised down the PCH through Malibu to see this wonderful art show <a href="http://www.ashesandsnow.org/">Ashes and Snow</a> adjacent to the Santa Monica Pier. This is a fabulous show, spiritually moving, sensual and powerful. Highly recommended, check it out. After a lovely dinner with April's godmother in Malibu, we drove back to Ojai and went to Joan Kemper's pad up on Saddle Mountain where a handful of Ojai moguls met to discuss this new pageant play "Ojai Rising" that Scott Campbell is putting together. More on that later. Here's to love and art. Peace.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Chris Wilson at 09:20 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/03/saw_ashes_and_snow_loved_it.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/03/saw_ashes_and_snow_loved_it.shtml#comments">Comments (4)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../chris.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                     </div>

                     <h2 class="date-header">March 06, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000374"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-374">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Sunny Morning Bike Ride to the Grocery</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>This is my first blog post ever...</p>

<p>Could be any day that I hop on the bike for a breakfasty ride up the path toward Starr Market. Crossing Montgomery I here a soft guitar and the soulful chirp of late boyhood. I briefly forget the grocery mission and turn to hear more. I pull up to a small gathering with familiar faces, a friendly enough bunch welcoming Charlie "Chaz" Benton's Gallery, <a href="http://www.brettdennen.com">Brett Dennen</a> is making sweet crushed velvet folk music. Charlie says "hello" and welcomes me inside for sparkling bevarage and baked goods.  I like Chaz' paintings, beautifully folky with vibrant colors and vintage frames. And I like his gallery: A little bit of pottery and a few other artists, not much more than a shoe box in the <a href="http://www.firehouse-pottery.com/">Firehouse</a> next door to the Art Center. </p>

<p>Where's your website Charlie?</p>

<p>And after a rich, buttery cookie, I duck back outside and continue on my way, rolling down the back pathway and over the Art Center bridge. I sidle through Libbey Park thinking about how lucky I am to be a human in this fine spot on the planet. </p>

<p>That's a rainy Monday Ojai memory.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Chris Wilson at 01:02 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/03/sunny_morning_bike_ride_to_the.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                 | <a href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/03/sunny_morning_bike_ride_to_the.shtml#comments">Comments (3)</a> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../chris.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>

                     <h2 class="date-header">February 27, 2006</h2>
                     <a id="a000343"></a>
                     <div class="entry" id="entry-343">
                        <h3 class="entry-header">Welcome to The Ojai Post!</h3>
                        <div class="entry-content">
                           <div class="entry-body">
                              <p>The Ojai Post is a community blog, featuring Ojai residents from all walks of life writing about the unique Ojai experience.  Ojai is a special place, not just for its geography, flora and fauna, small-town architecture and rich native American history - its also because of the people - talented, creative souls who tend to walk to the beat of their own drummer and carve their own path through life.   Check in for daily musings, rants, Ojai news and greater goings-on from the place some call Shangri-La.</p>
                              
                              <p class="entry-footer">
                                 <span class="post-footers">Posted by Tyler Suchman at 02:07 PM</span> <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="http://www.ojaipost.com/2006/02/welcome_to_the_ojai_post.shtml">Permalink</a>
                                  <span class="separator">|</span> <a class="permalink" href="../tyler.shtml">author bio</a>
                              </p>
                           </div>
